messages.text:
Hey guys. wilkins from Manifold here. We actually have an implementation and spec of this exact paradigm (we called it the “backpack”) that we were in progress of launching. Great minds. :)

There are some differing design decisions though, although minor. Was wondering if you would be open to collaboration and discussion about what your stance would be on the differing elements. Would be great to unify the standard if possible.

text_entities.text:
Hey guys. wilkins from Manifold here. We actually have an implementation and spec of this exact paradigm (we called it the “backpack”) that we were in progress of launching. Great minds. :)

There are some differing design decisions though, although minor. Was wondering if you would be open to collaboration and discussion about what your stance would be on the differing elements. Would be great to unify the standard if possible.

messages.text: Absolutely! Let’s organize a meeting this Friday? Would love to collab

text_entities.text: Absolutely! Let’s organize a meeting this Friday? Would love to collab

text: Also if you are heading to NYC apr 14th would love to have you at the meetup

text_entities.text: Also if you are heading to NYC apr 14th would love to have you at the meetup
https://partiful.com/e/PPdLPTnyk5DfRUcH72VS

messages.text:
The main differing elements were:
1. Upgradeable wallets
2. Standard implementation proxy bytecode (factory) which has an upgradeable implementation
3. Multiple token bound accounts possible in ours as well, but the way that’s done is deterministic. 
4. An interface in the implementation that allows marketplaces to handle the security vulnerability pointed out easily.

text_entities.text:
The main differing elements were:
1. Upgradeable wallets
2. Standard implementation proxy bytecode (factory) which has an upgradeable implementation
3. Multiple token bound accounts possible in ours as well, but the way that’s done is deterministic. 
4. An interface in the implementation that allows marketplaces to handle the security vulnerability pointed out easily.

text: Hi

We're probably building "the first" project based on 6551 which started 3 months ago. It's a desktop pet chrome extension users can upgrade and customize the NFT based on their on-chain activities. A little leak here:
. We're happy to bolster up the adoption for token bound accounts together!!!

text_entities.text: Hi
@bennyg

We're probably building "the first" project based on 6551 which started 3 months ago. It's a desktop pet chrome extension users can upgrade and customize the NFT based on their on-chain activities. A little leak here:
https://twitter.com/sofamon_xyz/status/1641941885819420672?s=20
. We're happy to bolster up the adoption for token bound accounts together!!!

messages.text: In our case, the Sofamon itself is a NFT and also a wallet. Then we visualize users wallet/NFT as a desktop buddy so that users can interact with blockchain like playing a mmorpg game

text_entities.text: In our case, the Sofamon itself is a NFT and also a wallet. Then we visualize users wallet/NFT as a desktop buddy so that users can interact with blockchain like playing a mmorpg game

messages.text: This is the perfect use case for 6551! Digital outfits and items are a natural fit and it’s just a beginning since the standard turns all NFTs to almost a folder structure it could open up a myriad of game use cases that require inventory systems.

messages.text:
Hey all - just joined via Benny. See a few familiar faces here! I was not aware of the proposal until today, but I'm working on a project that has been planning to build out NFT wallets for our use case and subsequently make the tech available for all NFTs. We're happy to find a group of folks that are underway with this already! 

Looking forward to exploring what has been accomplished so far and figuring out how we can collaborate on this ❤️

messages.text:
👋 I’ve zeroed an opportunity to implement 6551 for a web3 auto-chess game that I want to bring to market (85% complete).  I can shape the NFT strategy and have some ideas along the same use case as the Sapienz collection but with in-game impact… I’m interested to have a deeper discussion to learn more about what’s possible and get some feedback. 

The 5v5 auto-chess/auto-battler game is called “What The Funge,” .. pretty fun and silly. Characters are Funges you can buy in pack drops. We have a default set and we’re working with other collections to onboard some of their PFPs to create additional sets of Funges with stats etc., that can battle. 

I’ll drop in a Notion with more this week. I’ll also be at the Tokenbound event and looking forward to meeting everyone.

messages.text:
Tokenized RWA are easily going to approach a trillion dollar market on top of purely digital assets. Citibank (fwiw) recently called it a “the killer use case” that blockchain needs to drive. 

I’ve been thinking more deeply about implications of the 6551 for digital and RWA, and you can apply it seemingly to just about anything that’s ‘complex’ as defined simply by “holds other assets.”  

Examples of complex assets could be: 

- A land title NFT with the accompanying paperwork, housing blueprints, history of work on the property etc., 

- A car NFT that holds its components like the infotainment system, rims, muffler, etc., 

- A sports team (esports team) like the Vancouver Grizzlies (RIP) and its player contracts, merchandising agreements, etc.,  (THIS one I love, I want to build it if anyone else is keen. You can operationalize the entire mechanics of a sports league with smart contracts and tokens, I started some work last year). 

Other interesting patterns: 

- A “family tree” with seemingly unlimited branches and paths. Can contain family documents, old pictures, records etc., 

I’m not sure if the nomenclature of “complex” works here, but I thought it provided an easy way for a new user of the 6551 to understand appropriate use cases broadly. You’ll have to help me to understand if differentiating ‘complex’ from ‘simple’ (meaning shouldn’t hold anything else, like an atomic component of a complex asset) makes sense. In that case a simple asset would be like your classic 721, which although now endowed with the ability to own an account, and other assets, perhaps shouldn’t in some cases?

messages.text: A few thoughts: one, as-is there’s no way to support deploying wallets to the same account cross-chain. This will lead to people losing funds and not being able to recover them by mistakenly transferring to their wallet on the wrong chain, and more generally it’d be pretty sweet to be able to have a single account on multiple chains that’s ultimately controlled by an NFT on a specific chain

text_entities.text: A few thoughts: one, as-is there’s no way to support deploying wallets to the same account cross-chain. This will lead to people losing funds and not being able to recover them by mistakenly transferring to their wallet on the wrong chain, and more generally it’d be pretty sweet to be able to have a single account on multiple chains that’s ultimately controlled by an NFT on a specific chain

messages.text: Another potential danger is that as-is anyone can deploy a wallet for any NFT without that NFT owner’s permission; it might make sense to require that the caller is the owner of the NFT in question, or to submit a 712 signature from that owner as a prerequisite for deployment

text_entities.text: Another potential danger is that as-is anyone can deploy a wallet for any NFT without that NFT owner’s permission; it might make sense to require that the caller is the owner of the NFT in question, or to submit a 712 signature from that owner as a prerequisite for deployment

text: One more thought: if 1167 is already being modified to add extra data in the footer, it might make sense to go with a slightly better minimal proxy; I proposed this one a while back

text_entities.text: One more thought: if 1167 is already being modified to add extra data in the footer, it might make sense to go with a slightly better minimal proxy; I proposed this one a while back
https://medium.com/coinmonks/the-more-minimal-proxy-5756ae08ee48

messages.text: The chainId should be removed from the footer if multichain wallets are to be supported, and there’s no reason to encode the token address with 32 bytes in the footer and increase deployment costs by 2400 gas for the 12 unnecessary zeroes; I’d even propose a more compact encoding for address & tokenID (definitely the tokenID) where the first byte represents the number of bytes required to contain the value, followed by the value

messages.text: curious to hear more about your cross-chain concerns. Assuming the wallet implementation and registry addresses are static across chains, you should be able to deploy the same wallet at the same address across chains by passing in the same chain id, token contract address, and token id. It's of course up to the wallet implementation to support cross-chain calls, but that's outside the scope of the EIP.

text: Welcome everyone! As you know we have the first working group meet up in NYC later today. In this meetup we will be announcing companies or projects that are supporting 6551 and are planning to experiment/use it. We already have around 15 confirmed supporters. If you are interested in being mentioned or displayed in the presentation. Please send me the following. DM me here
or email

1. Name of project or company
2. Website
3. SVG or transparent PNG logo (black version is possible) 
4. How you plan to use 6551 within your project

As you all now 6551 is an open standard. As stewards our goal is to work together with the broader community to help build consensus so we can move the proposal towards finalization. Thank you 🙏

messages.text:
You've done a really great job here! 

I've been bullish on nesting NFTs since the end of 2020. Glad that it's being turned into a proper EIP now. Back then there was Charged Particles protocol which was trying to do the same, but they chose a walled garden scenario which has totally killed them imo.

text_entities.text:
You've done a really great job here! 

I've been bullish on nesting NFTs since the end of 2020. Glad that it's being turned into a proper EIP now. Back then there was Charged Particles protocol which was trying to do the same, but they chose a walled garden scenario which has totally killed them imo.

text:
Back then I was running a Kool-Aid themed meme project where users could mint ERC-1155 flavors of Kool-Aid (we didn't care about copyrights much back then XD) and mix (burn) them in various proportions to get rarer ones. 

We wanted to make a 2nd season where each common flavor would be minted out of some native

token + some other popular ERC-20 and then mix them so rare flavors absorb all the ingredients and become baskets of assets. However, there weren't any good L2 options available back then and doing something like that on ETH would be too terribly gas-inefficient so we eventually scrapped that idea. ERC-6551 makes me want to try it again on Arbitrum maybe

text_entities.text:
Back then I was running a Kool-Aid themed meme project where users could mint ERC-1155 flavors of Kool-Aid (we didn't care about copyrights much back then XD) and mix (burn) them in various proportions to get rarer ones. 

We wanted to make a 2nd season where each common flavor would be minted out of some native
$KOOL

token + some other popular ERC-20 and then mix them so rare flavors absorb all the ingredients and become baskets of assets. However, there weren't any good L2 options available back then and doing something like that on ETH would be too terribly gas-inefficient so we eventually scrapped that idea. ERC-6551 makes me want to try it again on Arbitrum maybe

messages.text:
^that's exactly the reason why we worked with this community to create this standard! we tried and looked at everything out there! Been working and building onchain game mechanics since CK, Cheeze Wizards, STAPLEVERSE, etc. but everytime it was like bashing your head against the wall.

1. [on-chain inside of the NFT contract] Charged Particles, RMRK, ERC998, etc. Resulted in walled gardens, doesn't work with existing NFTs, limited to some on-chain assets (like 721)

2. [on-chain external contracts] space doodles, wrapped, etc. Can't modify existing NFTs and had limitations, custom contract development (costly and potential security risk), poor conversion because NFT owners have to take the onchain action 

3. [offchain] this one is straight forward. centralized. expensive to build and maintain. not contributing to the common good. 

All 3 options would have difficulty on adoption and created uneven playing fields that is in favour of projects with a lot of $$$ and can afford custom contracts or offchain infra. Existing platforms like marketplaces, wallets, dapps didn't know how to handle all of these custom contracts and therefore created an adoption challenge.

ERC 6551 as a open source standard is trying to solve that problem by:

- backwards compatable with every single NFT 
- out of the box support for all onchain assets (20, 721, 1155, etc)
- give power back to the NFT owner where they can control/add logic to their NFTs intead of being at the mercy of the project creators
- 10x easier to integrate (see SDK). Plus uses wallet infra that has existed for many years. 
- Infinitely flexible and open to anyone to build on top of

Existing platforms like marketplaces, wallets, dapps didn't know how to handle all of these custom contracts and therefore created an adoption challenge.

ERC 6551 as a open source standard is trying to solve that problem by:

- 10x easier to integrate (see SDK). Plus uses wallet infra that has existed for many years. 
- Infinitely flexible and open to anyone to build on top of

messages.text:
Hello, Marc from Animoca here. Thinking of using 6551 for character loadouts in games. 

2 questions:
- Could we impose restrictions on what NFTs can be transferred to the wallet? (E.g. only 1 of each item type, or only items of a specific metadata attribute)
- How do you imagine the UX for 6551 to look like? For example on OpenSea, we’d probably want them to aggregate the NFTs that belong. I know it’s early days on this but front end adoption would definitely help the game experience

text_entities.text:
Hello, Marc from Animoca here. Thinking of using 6551 for character loadouts in games. 

2 questions:
- Could we impose restrictions on what NFTs can be transferred to the wallet? (E.g. only 1 of each item type, or only items of a specific metadata attribute)
- How do you imagine the UX for 6551 to look like? For example on OpenSea, we’d probably want them to aggregate the NFTs that belong. I know it’s early days on this but front end adoption would definitely help the game experience

messages.text: Circling back to the first question, if it was a Diablo style game we’d want to ensure that the character has only 1x hat, 2x gloves etc and that they are attributes that match the class of the character

messages.text: To expand on this, eip6551 allows anyone to specify their own implementation. Effectively, each implementation can be viewed as its own “namespace”. You can restrict what that wallet can receive (Eg you could reject any transfers aside from an nft transfer) or even prevent creation of working wallets  for non-approved tokens (by implementing an initialize function with a check)

text: Great questions! You can definitely restrict NFTs going to a given token bound account. The simplest way to do so is to implement a hard ownership cap per-wallet at the NFT contract level if the owner is a token bound account. This way you don't need to implement a whole smart contract wallet just to enforce ownership rules. You can also override the onERC721Received method on a custom account implementation as
mentioned. If you're planning to use the open-source account implementation, you could also add this logic as an extension

text_entities.text: Great questions! You can definitely restrict NFTs going to a given token bound account. The simplest way to do so is to implement a hard ownership cap per-wallet at the NFT contract level if the owner is a token bound account. This way you don't need to implement a whole smart contract wallet just to enforce ownership rules. You can also override the onERC721Received method on a custom account implementation as
@zomglings
mentioned. If you're planning to use the open-source account implementation, you could also add this logic as an extension

messages.text:
Yes accounts could use different implementations (smart contract standards) their is a default one provided based on what Manifold and Future Primitive has worked on and have audited. But theoritically you can create your own implementation which modifies functionalities. 

There's also opportunity to add extensions onto tokenbound accounts that can add utility such as nesting, staking, burn, etc. 

Extensions are going to be much safer and easier to build and use. While implementations will be more custom contracts and will have more flexibility but will require more resources and audits.

messages.text: GM all! Got a qq, what's the cleanest pattern you know for updating a single NFT metadata within a collection without re-uploading an entire IPFS batch? I have some approaches but want to double check if they're sound.

text_entities.text: GM all! Got a qq, what's the cleanest pattern you know for updating a single NFT metadata within a collection without re-uploading an entire IPFS batch? I have some approaches but want to double check if they're sound.

messages.text: Is the existing metadata on IPFS? And do you have control over per-token metadata URIs at the contract level? Is the contract immutable or upgradable?

text_entities.text: Is the existing metadata on IPFS? And do you have control over per-token metadata URIs at the contract level? Is the contract immutable or upgradable?

messages.text: for a new contract, not existing. Upgradeable. Control over per-token metadata URI.

) so changes are reflected on marketplaces

messages.text: Is there anything preventing a token’s owner address to also be a wallet that is bound to the token? I’m wondering if it’s possible for a token to somehow own itself?

text_entities.text: Is there anything preventing a token’s owner address to also be a wallet that is bound to the token? I’m wondering if it’s possible for a token to somehow own itself?

text: This is possible, and something that the EIP leaves open for account implementations to handle as they see fit (see:

). If an NFT owns itself, the NFT and the account contents are essentially burned. The Tokenbound account implementation provides some contract level protection against this, but it's difficult to fully prevent on-chain because of the large search space. Clients are encouraged to prevent users from accidentally introducing ownership cycles. Hope that helps :)

text_entities.text: This is possible, and something that the EIP leaves open for account implementations to handle as they see fit (see:
https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-6551#ownership-cycles

). If an NFT owns itself, the NFT and the account contents are essentially burned. The Tokenbound account implementation provides some contract level protection against this, but it's difficult to fully prevent on-chain because of the large search space. Clients are encouraged to prevent users from accidentally introducing ownership cycles. Hope that helps :)

messages.text:
Hey guys, very excited by tokenbound NFTs. I believe this enables strong new use cases going further than 4337.

Many financial use cases are made possible by this, and I've been thinking about said use cases these past months (without relying on a solution, only in a "speculative" way)

I'm non techie but I talked about erc6551 with some friends at some layer2s / protocols and they'd be interested to engage in talks with some of you to see how to foster adoption of such a great erc.

Feel free to hit me up 🙂

text: Does it need to say nft? What if there eth inside or other coins ?  Just an idea but did you explore just numerical value base on floor price of all additional assets it holds ? It's a quick way to understand how much value is nft vs what it holds

text_entities.text: @bennyg

Does it need to say nft? What if there eth inside or other coins ?  Just an idea but did you explore just numerical value base on floor price of all additional assets it holds ? It's a quick way to understand how much value is nft vs what it holds

messages.text:
Interesting idea! Most wallets like Metamask seperate Assets (coins) and NFTs. Being that TBAs can hold either assets or NFTs we originally had the word "Assets" but... we felt it was confusing because does 10 ETH = 1 asset? we know that 1 NFT = 1 asset. So what would the total be?

If we go for the other option where we just show total value, I guess we can basically sum up all the nested NFT's floor price + total coins and it would just display an ETH value like "10.5 ETH" but I wonder if people might get confused and think that would be the price of the NFT (which could be the reaction we want?)

text_entities.text:

If we go for the other option where we just show total value, I guess we can basically sum up all the nested NFT's floor price + total coins and it would just display an ETH value like "10.5 ETH" but I wonder if people might get confused and think that would be the price of the NFT (which could be the reaction we want?)

text:
: I've been thinking more about ERC6551 since our call last week, especially about tokenbound accounts in the context of web3 games.

Two thoughts:

1. One of the problems with the NFT Inventory contract is in how to handle backpacks. These are storage positions which can accept any item and based on the level of your backpack you may have different numbers of these positions. An ERC6551 contract with an appropriately modified

callback could be really good for this.

2. One of the leading patterns in fully on-chain games is to transfer ownership of your NFT to a game contract. This pattern doesn't play well with ERC6551 for many reasons. I'm trying to understand if this could be solved with a custom ERC6551 account implementation.

text_entities.text: @jaydenwindle

: I've been thinking more about ERC6551 since our call last week, especially about tokenbound accounts in the context of web3 games.

Two thoughts:

1. One of the problems with the NFT Inventory contract is in how to handle backpacks. These are storage positions which can accept any item and based on the level of your backpack you may have different numbers of these positions. An ERC6551 contract with an appropriately modified
onERC721Received

callback could be really good for this.

2. One of the leading patterns in fully on-chain games is to transfer ownership of your NFT to a game contract. This pattern doesn't play well with ERC6551 for many reasons. I'm trying to understand if this could be solved with a custom ERC6551 account implementation.

messages.text:
These are great questions! A few thoughts:

1. You're right that 6551 has no concept of equippable slots. Modifying the receiver is one way to implement, but perhaps a better way is to have an external contract that manages the mapping between items in the 6551 account and the slots they are equipped to. 6551 handles the "does this nft own this item" problem, the mapping contract would solve the "is this nft able to use this item in a way that matches the in-game logic" problem.

2. Would love to hear more about why this pattern doesn't play well with 6551! If the game contract owns t he NFT, the game contract has full control over the nft wallet, which seems like a nice feature as it can manage inventory on the token's behalf. Additionally, since each token has a static wallet, storing the nft in the game contract might not be necessary (since it seems like there would be less reasons to restrict transfers). The execution permission on the account could be delegated to the game logic contract, allowing transfers to happen at any time without interfering with game logic

Modifying the receiver is one way to implement, but perhaps a better way is to have an external contract that manages the mapping between items in the 6551 account and the slots they are equipped to. 6551 handles the "does this nft own this item" problem, the mapping contract would solve the "is this nft able to use this item in a way that matches the in-game logic" problem.

2. Would love to hear more about why this pattern doesn't play well with 6551! If the game contract owns t he NFT, the game contract has full control over the nft wallet, which seems like a nice feature as it can manage inventory on the token's behalf. Additionally, since each token has a static wallet, storing the nft in the game contract might not be necessary (since it seems like there would be less reasons to restrict transfers). The execution permission on the account could be delegated to the game logic contract, allowing transfers to happen at any time without interfering with game logic

text: 1. The NFT Inventory contract stores the mapping between ERC721 tokens and items. It also assumes ownership of items:
The custom implementation I was considering for an ERC6551 account would expose the inventory interface so players could easily equip/unequip by making calls directly to the 6551 account (by proxy).

text_entities.text: 1. The NFT Inventory contract stores the mapping between ERC721 tokens and items. It also assumes ownership of items:
https://github.com/G7DAO/contracts/blob/develop/contracts/facets/InventoryFacet.sol
The custom implementation I was considering for an ERC6551 account would expose the inventory interface so players could easily equip/unequip by making calls directly to the 6551 account (by proxy).

messages.text: 2. re: not storing the NFT in the game contract that still imposes game design constraints. For example, we build our game mechanics without assumptions on the ERC721 implementation - and we can't assume that a player is using a tokenbound account with their NFT.

text_entities.text: 2. re: not storing the NFT in the game contract that still imposes game design constraints. For example, we build our game mechanics without assumptions on the ERC721 implementation - and we can't assume that a player is using a tokenbound account with their NFT.

messages.text: Would love to hear more about some of the constraints that are important to you right now. If every NFT has a tokenbound account by default regardless of NFT implementation, why can't that be assumed?

text_entities.text: Would love to hear more about some of the constraints that are important to you right now. If every NFT has a tokenbound account by default regardless of NFT implementation, why can't that be assumed?

messages.text:
Most important factor for us is that we can deploy our game mechanics into any game world in a consistent manner.

Every NFT has a tokenbound account (in principle) but that doesn't mean that the current owner of that NFT is aware of the tokenbound account or gives their consent to send new game assets to that tokenbound account.

text_entities.text:
Most important factor for us is that we can deploy our game mechanics into any game world in a consistent manner.

Every NFT has a tokenbound account (in principle) but that doesn't mean that the current owner of that NFT is aware of the tokenbound account or gives their consent to send new game assets to that tokenbound account.

messages.text: Totally agree re: game world consistency. Why does the NFT owner need to be aware of the tokenbound account or give consent to receiving assets? The game is able to deploy the account on behalf of the token holder, and is able to permissionlessly send assets to it. If the token holder interacts with the game via their tokenbound account or transfers their NFT to the game contract, isn't that implicit consent to use it? I guess I don't see how assuming the (already guaranteed) existence of a tokenbound account is any different than the asssumptions that are already being made

text_entities.text: Totally agree re: game world consistency. Why does the NFT owner need to be aware of the tokenbound account or give consent to receiving assets? The game is able to deploy the account on behalf of the token holder, and is able to permissionlessly send assets to it. If the token holder interacts with the game via their tokenbound account or transfers their NFT to the game contract, isn't that implicit consent to use it? I guess I don't see how assuming the (already guaranteed) existence of a tokenbound account is any different than the asssumptions that are already being made

messages.text:
It's not mathematically equivalent to send assets to the tokenbound account and to send assets to the owner:
1. Someone has to submit an additional transaction to deploy the ERC6551 account.
2. If the owner of the NFT wants to make use of the assets that were transferred to the tokenbound account in some other context, they would have to submit a transaction to first transfer the assets from the tokenbound account to their account before doing whatever they wanted to do.

messages.text: Correct, which is partially why I'm not sure putting game logic in the receiver handler is the best solution. I don't think it makes sense to enforce game constraints at the level of the account, I think it makes sense to enforce game constraints at the level of the game logic contract. By assuming the account exists and is the means for determining ownership (not utility) for each in-game item, this means that the game logic doesn't need to manage ownership

text_entities.text: Correct, which is partially why I'm not sure putting game logic in the receiver handler is the best solution. I don't think it makes sense to enforce game constraints at the level of the account, I think it makes sense to enforce game constraints at the level of the game logic contract. By assuming the account exists and is the means for determining ownership (not utility) for each in-game item, this means that the game logic doesn't need to manage ownership

messages.text: I don't think this is necessary so long as the account isn't the source of truth for game logic constraints. For example, imagine I have an NFT that is compatible with two separate game worlds. If game logic constraints around valid items is enforced at the account level, I would need a separate account to interact with each game. However, if the item usage constraints are at the game logic level, I can use a single account for both games. This is simpler from both a user and a platform perspective (as each NFT owns all gaming-related assets in one place). Each game can still validate ownership of items and use of items according to it's own logic, while letting the NFT remain soverign over the assets it chooses to own. Would love to understand any challenges around using this model that you think might arise :)

messages.text:
thanks for the invite! Very excited about 6551 and the general concept of giving NFTs their own wallets.

I'm very keen to understand the degree to which 6551 does or could support 1155s. My main project (Hats Protocol) makes heavy use of non-transferable 1155s, and we're highly interested in giving each its own wallet (recognizing that there are some considerations related to variable supply and 1-of-n security models).

text_entities.text:
thanks for the invite! Very excited about 6551 and the general concept of giving NFTs their own wallets.

I'm very keen to understand the degree to which 6551 does or could support 1155s. My main project (Hats Protocol) makes heavy use of non-transferable 1155s, and we're highly interested in giving each its own wallet (recognizing that there are some considerations related to variable supply and 1-of-n security models).

text: Welcome

! 1155 support is an open question at the moment, primarily because it complicates the model significantly if there can be more than one owner per token ID. In your case, do the 1155 tokens have multiple owners or a single owner?

text_entities.text: Welcome
@spengrah

! 1155 support is an open question at the moment, primarily because it complicates the model significantly if there can be more than one owner per token ID. In your case, do the 1155 tokens have multiple owners or a single owner?

messages.text:
either, depending on the token. Each token (aka "hat") can be configured with a max supply up to 2^32. Many just have 1 owner, but many have multiple. This does make things harder to handle, primarily the 1-of-n security model I mentioned.

Our current thinking is to give our users multiple options, with the simple wallet implementation (ideally via 6551; we've hacked around with Mech) being the 1-of-n flavor.

messages.text: I think I saw somewhere that the intent of 6551 is to allow for multiple implementations. If that remains the case, I think that would help make 1155 support acceptible, since there wouldn't be an expectation of canonical wallet address for a given NFT and the default would be for users to choose.

text_entities.text: I think I saw somewhere that the intent of 6551 is to allow for multiple implementations. If that remains the case, I think that would help make 1155 support acceptible, since there wouldn't be an expectation of canonical wallet address for a given NFT and the default would be for users to choose.

messages.text: This is definitely correct, it would be quite simple to spin up an implementation that works with 1155s. The asterisk here is that it would require either a) a slightly non-standard account implementation or b) changes to the standard account interface within the proposal. The account interface currently specifies an "owner" function which returns a single canonical owner address. Since 1155s that can have multiple owners don't have a single canonical owner, this starts to break down. Would love to hear more about your thinking around 1-of-n execution, I'm very curious to hear the use case for allowing anyone who owns an 1155 token to be able to execute on behalf of all holders

text_entities.text: This is definitely correct, it would be quite simple to spin up an implementation that works with 1155s. Since 1155s that can have multiple owners don't have a single canonical owner, this starts to break down. Hey guys! 

Would you be interested in having a debate/discussion with Bruno from RMRK team which is behind EIP-6059? 6059 is trying to solve more or less the same problem as 6551 but with a bit different approach. I'm in the same NFT-related chat with Bruno and we discussed both standards a little. He says he'd be open to a discussion or collaboration. So I thought it could be a good idea to mediate it.

messages.text: Bruno would have a better grasp on this than I would, but from my reading of the standard 6059 allows NFTs that implement the standard to nest other NFTs that implement the standard inside of them. There's no NFT execution logic beyond nested ownership of specific assets. It's also not compatible with ERC20/ERC1155 tokens without wrapping them in an ERC721 token

messages.text:
Emblem Vault lets you mint NFTs which work as keys to a wallet (or array of wallets across different blockchains). When you burn the parent NFT you receive all the private keys. They’re using an off-chain solution for this, but the idea is that the platform itself doesn’t have any access to the keys generated. 

I think Emblem Vault is being used for Rare Pepe cards and Ordinals to make them trade able on ETH

messages.text: Great question! TBAs are compatible with safe / AA wallets / any smart contract account as owners by default. You can hold NFTs in your safe and use their TBAs out of the box. However, smart contract accounts like safe or other 4337 wallets will not work as 6551 implementations out of the box. In order to become compatible, they would need to implement the 6551 account interface and adjust their execution model to be token-based rather than signature based.

text_entities.text: Great question! TBAs are compatible with safe / AA wallets / any smart contract account as owners by default. You can hold NFTs in your safe and use their TBAs out of the box. However, smart contract accounts like safe or other 4337 wallets will not work as 6551 implementations out of the box. In order to become compatible, they would need to implement the 6551 account interface and adjust their execution model to be token-based rather than signature based.

messages.text: Would it be possible to have TBAs as a module in a Safe? This would allow that assets could be kept on a Safe without signers where the TBA is added as a module plugin. So assets can start off being NFT-bound but transition into a regular private key-controlled Smart Account later on (by the NFT holder adding signers and removing the module).

messages.text:
Moloch V3 is built on top of safe - and has these admin contracts called Shamans. 

The Shaman accepts a minimum tribute and if the minimum tribute is met, mints the nft to the acct. 

Then a TBA is created and registered to that NFT. 

This is possible because moloch v3, shares and loot are transferable erc20.

text_entities.text:
Moloch V3 is built on top of safe - and has these admin contracts called Shamans. 

The Shaman accepts a minimum tribute and if the minimum tribute is met, mints the nft to the acct. 

Then a TBA is created and registered to that NFT. 

This is possible because moloch v3, shares and loot are transferable erc20.

messages.text: Definitely something that can be implemented by account implementations, so far have been cautious about enforcing too many features in the account interface to avoid bloating the standard. But no reason a given account couldn't support 725 / other execution interfaces in addition to the current 6551 interface (which is wip)

text_entities.text: Definitely something that can be implemented by account implementations, so far have been cautious about enforcing too many features in the account interface to avoid bloating the standard. But no reason a given account couldn't support 725 / other execution interfaces in addition to the current 6551 interface (which is wip)

messages.text: I don’t think we should or need to enforce account interfaces as part of the spec. A 6551 account “can” support 725 or others, but shouldn’t be a must. There’s no reason to lock an implementation interface in, as the 6551 concept is around AA ownership rather than execution.

text_entities.text: I don’t think we should or need to enforce account interfaces as part of the spec. A 6551 account “can” support 725 or others, but shouldn’t be a must. There’s no reason to lock an implementation interface in, as the 6551 concept is around AA ownership rather than execution.

messages.text:
Any ideas in a app or game where items are attached to another nft (sent to the token bound account) what would be a proper way to manage attachements. For eg a character can carry a weapon but multiple weapon could be sent to one character. What would be the best way to keep the one in use? 
Add data (a bool) to the transfer to say if it will be used or not and only keep track of the one sent by the owner?

Would probably need some sort of order too like: if one weapon is damaged switch to the next one as attachement..

Any other ideas?

text: adding something like

would mean that, for 6551 accounts owned by EOAs (vs smart contracts, which would get batching "for free" though still inefficient), each subsequent batch call would be *at least* 28600 gas cheaper: 21000 baseline tx fee + 2600 cold
+ 2100 cold
sload + 2900 warm

sstore; more if you're sending ether with any/each tx

50gwei gas @ $1800 means a ~$3 difference on mainnet; optimism's base L1 fee for posting the tx is currently ~1/10 that, so each individual tx would still incur a ~$0.30 overhead on any op-stack L2

ie, i really _really_ think adding a batch endpoint to the official spec is worthwhile; smart wallets are already more expensive than EOAs, no need to make 6551 the worst-of-the-worst

messages.text: Batch calls are for sure table stakes for a smart contract wallet. I guess the concern is forcing a specific batch execution interface on all accounts vs letting accounts choose their own. I really do think it would be better to have a separate EIP for a universal smart contract account execution interface that this proposal could conform to, but in the absence of that I think you make a good case for including batch calls

messages.text: This is part of the reason for being hesitant to expand the required account interface - there are many use cases where certain desirable contract account features like batching might not be required for a certain implementation's use case. However that concern is balanced by the desire to make it easy for clients of these accounts to perform the most common actions with the same interface across all accounts. So still very much an open discussion over what should be the final interface :)

text: This is something

is adding to the tokenbound implementation. But I’m strongly against adding that to the 6551 spec itself. Why?

1. Like I mentioned 6551 is about ownership identification being passed onto the token. What you can do with that ownership information is open ended. 

2. Because it’s open ended, execution may not be the goal for a token bound account. It could simply be a depository repo or asset aggregator without an intent of separation. Also, with evolving standards with respect to execution logic, there’s no reason to bind 6551 to a spec, especially a non standard one. 

3. Consider things like delegation execution, etc. where do we stop? I think it’s sufficient for the spec to highlight possible implementations but not require them. 

I think about an actual end implementation as, this wallet is 6551+725. Or 6551+xyz. 

Rather than 6551 only.

Also, with evolving standards with respect to execution logic, there’s no reason to bind 6551 to a spec, especially a non standard one. 

3. Consider things like delegation execution, etc. where do we stop? I think it’s sufficient for the spec to highlight possible implementations but not require them. 

I think about an actual end implementation as, this wallet is 6551+725. Or 6551+xyz. 

Rather than 6551 only.

messages.text:
There’s two sides of this endeavor. First being the spec and what it encompasses. Second being the tokenbound site and providing a great useable default implementation. 

The latter should encompass things like batch execution, etc. But the former, from a spec perspective, should be focused on enabling multiple forms of implementation.

messages.text:
Side note. We are working on a composable display framework for 6551, in widget form. It’s going to be opinionated, it’s going to have customization behavior hooks. But we don’t expect it to be the “only” display layer for 6551 compatible implementations. 

I think there’s a good common basic view (Ie showing all assets), but I think it’s also too ambitious to believe that there will be a global view that makes sense for all possibilities. Even well used wallets don’t have display unification yet, nor support for all smart account implementations.

I think there’s a good common basic view (Ie showing all assets), but I think it’s also too ambitious to believe that there will be a global view that makes sense for all possibilities. Even well used wallets don’t have display unification yet, nor support for all smart account implementations.

text:
Hey all! Following up from the dev call this morning.

Here’s the link to claim your TBA membership:

The wallet enables you to accrue and showcase reputation of your contribution to this group. For those who were in the dev call earlier, you should see the participation badge in your TBA wallet 😊

Storing and showcasing attendance participation only scratches the surface for what membership wallets enabled by 6551 can do. 

We’d love input from the community to see how we leverage this collection to experiment on how programmatic membership, enabled by 6551, can enable orgs to run more autonomously, bringing us a step closer to the vision of DAOs.

messages.text: I disagree with the philosophy around this spec btw. It goes against the ethos of self sovereignty and ownership, especially in the mechanisms that are likely not bypassed. If you have to be on a whitelist to transfer, who’s really in control? Also completely breaks AA and 6551 ownership.

messages.text:
Personally, my thesis is that those who implement restrictive systems will have a much harder time getting initial traction than those who do not, especially if passive income is a large part of their strategy. Why? For the “flippers”, they will gravitate towards low fee products as it leads to more efficient marketplaces (fees and royalties artificially increase the spread). So they’ll gravitate towards products and nft’s that do not have this (see blur). 

On the flip side, with proper incentive systems for royalty participation, you’ll likely have greater community participation (Eg airdrops and allowlist based on hold period + royalties paid). 

To me, these proposals of locking down transfers are just applying web2 philosophies in web3 in a very bad way. Driving ppl to only engage on sanctioned platforms. At the extreme, what’s the difference between that and web2? You lose out on the potential of web3: permission-less compatibility, self custody, etc.

So they’ll gravitate towards products and nft’s that do not have this (see blur). 

On the flip side, with proper incentive systems for royalty participation, you’ll likely have greater community participation (Eg airdrops and allowlist based on hold period + royalties paid). 

To me, these proposals of locking down transfers are just applying web2 philosophies in web3 in a very bad way. Driving ppl to only engage on sanctioned platforms. At the extreme, what’s the difference between that and web2? You lose out on the potential of web3: permission-less compatibility, self custody, etc.

I have a quick quesiton on something I seem to be misunderstanding:
-When we deploy a new TBA from the registry is that deployment a clone using the create2 op code? My understanding was that clones are not deployed with the CREATE opcode that's how the whole gas saving side of EIP1167 works. Hope someone can clarify this for me. Thank you!

text_entities.text:
Hey everyone thanks for putting this telegram group here!
I have a quick quesiton on something I seem to be misunderstanding:
-When we deploy a new TBA from the registry is that deployment a clone using the create2 op code? My understanding was that clones are not deployed with the CREATE opcode that's how the whole gas saving side of EIP1167 works. Hope someone can clarify this for me. Thank you!

messages.text: Definitely possible with a bridge!

text_entities.text: Definitely possible with a bridge!

messages.text: Yep, token bound accounts are deployed using create2, which gives every NFT a deterministic address. create2 and create both cost the same amount of gas, it's the bytecode size of 1167 that provides the savings

text_entities.text: Yep, token bound accounts are deployed using create2, which gives every NFT a deterministic address. create2 and create both cost the same amount of gas, it's the bytecode size of 1167 that provides the savings

messages.text: Hey Jayden, thanks for the quick response! So just to confirm, we're still paying the ~32k for deployment for the use of the op code but deploying a smaller bytecode size (and saving costs there)?

text_entities.text: Hey Jayden, thanks for the quick response! So just to confirm, we're still paying the ~32k for deployment for the use of the op code but deploying a smaller bytecode size (and saving costs there)?

messages.text: Yep, exactly

text_entities.text: Yep, exactly

text:
Thank you everyone for joining this working group! A few important rules:

1. Everyone here is a builder and actively providing opinions or contributing to the open source standard

2. We'll try to keep memes to a minimum and will enforce if it gets too out of hands. The purpose of this group is to build together and to share work or ask questions about ERC 6551

3. We have weekly dev/design calls on Thursdays
4. At any time, we encourage people to share their MVPs or projects using ERC 6551/TBAs. Mint your ERC 6551 membership NFT powered by 0xStation as a fun experiment

5. We're here to rally the community towards making NFTs an awesome thing to own and collect. We mostly come from a development perspective rather than a shilling one, so please be mindful of that

6. The biggest contribuition you can make to this open standard is to share your feedback here:
7. If you have any issues with the SDK

or with anything feel free to share your questions in this group

8. Be nice. Be friendly. Be helpful to each other. No harrassment is tolerated and will be removed immediately. 

9. All constructive ideas are welcomed and we encourage healthy debates. We are aware that the NFT ecosystem is huge and there are so many projects that have different use cases. ERC 6551 is designed to be flexible, composable, and open so that anyone can customize it as they see fit.

10. When referencing ERC 6551 we usually call them Token Bound Accounts (TBAs). That is the most technically correct term.

11. Submit your project to the community page

text_entities.text:
Thank you everyone for joining this working group! A few important rules:

1. Everyone here is a builder and actively providing opinions or contributing to the open source standard

2. We'll try to keep memes to a minimum and will enforce if it gets too out of hands. The purpose of this group is to build together and to share work or ask questions about ERC 6551

3. We have weekly dev/design calls on Thursdays
https://calendar.google.com/calendar/u/1/r?cid=Y185OTNjZmNjOGRjNWE5MDdlM2Y1N2M4YWI0NTQwYzRiMTVhNTQ4ODc2YmQ0OWMyMWEwYmExY2RkMGU2MDE4ZjVhQGdyb3VwLmNhbGVuZGFyLmdvb2dsZS5jb20
4. At any time, we encourage people to share their MVPs or projects using ERC 6551/TBAs. Mint your ERC 6551 membership NFT powered by 0xStation as a fun experiment
https://members.station.express/matic:0x10e0ad62eef221ea562a9d5db80c25629c419d15/directory

5. We're here to rally the community towards making NFTs an awesome thing to own and collect. We mostly come from a development perspective rather than a shilling one, so please be mindful of that

6. The biggest contribuition you can make to this open standard is to share your feedback here:
https://ethereum-magicians.org/t/erc-6551-non-fungible-token-bound-accounts/13030
7. If you have any issues with the SDK
https://docs.tokenbound.org/

or with anything feel free to share your questions in this group

8. Be nice. Be friendly. Be helpful to each other. No harrassment is tolerated and will be removed immediately. 

9. All constructive ideas are welcomed and we encourage healthy debates. We are aware that the NFT ecosystem is huge and there are so many projects that have different use cases. ERC 6551 is designed to be flexible, composable, and open so that anyone can customize it as they see fit.

10. When referencing ERC 6551 we usually call them Token Bound Accounts (TBAs). That is the most technically correct term.

11. Submit your project to the community page
https://forms.gle/S3c4SQqC6bDK4x9u8

Hey everyone! I have a couple questions was hoping to clarify. Thanks very much!

1) What is the difference between ERC6551 and ERC4337? Are they complimentary? I know in 6551 we leverage NFTs as the owner so not sure how that plays out in ERC4337

2) It says in the comment for the
function that when we transfer the nft that controls the account the executors get reset. Where and how does this happen? I don't see any logic for this in the
function in this file (

text_entities.text:
Hey everyone! I have a couple questions was hoping to clarify. Thanks very much!

1) What is the difference between ERC6551 and ERC4337? Are they complimentary? I know in 6551 we leverage NFTs as the owner so not sure how that plays out in ERC4337

2) It says in the comment for the
function setExecutor(){}
function that when we transfer the nft that controls the account the executors get reset. Where and how does this happen? I don't see any logic for this in the
setExecutor()
function in this file (
https://github.com/tokenbound/contracts/blob/main/src/Account.sol

messages.text:
Great questions!
1) They're complimentary - ERC-6551 accounts can also be ERC-4337 accounts. ERC-6551 is focused on binding accounts to tokens, whereas ERC-4337 is focused on creating a decentralized network to power abstract accounts
2) This happens because executors are contained in a mapping that includes the current owner as part of the mapping key. When the owner changes, the mapping key changes, causing all previously authorized executors to be de-authorized for the new owner

messages.text:
Okay so correct me if I'm wrong here and maybe I missed something along the process of deployment!

I started out by deploying both the account and registry contracts, I took the account contract address and used it for the implementation, along with the chainId, tokenContract, tokenID, and salt. I created the token-bound account and then grabbed the token-bound account address from the account read function on the registry. So I'm assuming that token-bound account is the one linked to the NFT right? When I query ownerOf on the erc721 contract with the same tokenId, it says the owner is my personal address and not the token-bound account, which makes sense. But I guess I am confused on how I can truly control access of that token-bound account to run transactions with it and not just accept things from another EOA. I guess what I'm asking is is there a way for me to like import that token-bound address into my metamask or am I way off here haha

text_entities.text:
Okay so correct me if I'm wrong here and maybe I missed something along the process of deployment!

I started out by deploying both the account and registry contracts, I took the account contract address and used it for the implementation, along with the chainId, tokenContract, tokenID, and salt. I created the token-bound account and then grabbed the token-bound account address from the account read function on the registry. So I'm assuming that token-bound account is the one linked to the NFT right? When I query ownerOf on the erc721 contract with the same tokenId, it says the owner is my personal address and not the token-bound account, which makes sense. But I guess I am confused on how I can truly control access of that token-bound account to run transactions with it and not just accept things from another EOA. I guess what I'm asking is is there a way for me to like import that token-bound address into my metamask or am I way off here haha

text: Ah yes - there's no way to import the tokenbound account into your metamask (...yet 😉). However, your EOA that owns the NFT will have full permissions on the token bound account. You will need to sign with the owner wallet in order to execute transactions from your token bound account. You can use
to interact with your account and execute transactions, and can also do so from etherscan directly. If you're building apps on top of 6551, you can use the SDK to interact with the account.

text_entities.text: Ah yes - there's no way to import the tokenbound account into your metamask (...yet 😉). However, your EOA that owns the NFT will have full permissions on the token bound account. You will need to sign with the owner wallet in order to execute transactions from your token bound account. You can use
tokenbound.org
to interact with your account and execute transactions, and can also do so from etherscan directly. If you're building apps on top of 6551, you can use the SDK to interact with the account.

text: hello good people and Benny thanks for the invite, excited to be here! As promised a lil intro to us: We (Talk Time, an indie pop duo out of LA experimenting in web3 since early 2021) are building our next gen interactive album with Props Labs and we're looking at experimenting with 6551! We put out the first multi-track album as one token on the blockchain last year (

) and I hope to continue to innovate in the music space and have some fun plans for the Gen-2 player that we're building with our fantastic dev team at Props (devs behind Deadfellaz, Woodies, + more). Originally had pitched to them to try using ERC-998 but 6551 seems to have more flexibility and excited to learn more and see what everyone is building here. Cheers! --Mike

messages.text: Yes, this is planned as a feature in the tokenbound account implementation! It requires a trusted cross-chain executor contract, which isn't quite ready for prime time yet. But we are working with several partners for whom this is a key use case :)

messages.text:
Hey Mike, this is legit!
One of our projects is a Fantasy Football League (with a bit of a twist).
The 6551 use case is perfect for building a "franchise" where team owners can nest their individual playing cards under their franchise "Owner's Pass NFT".

One of the struggles that we had last year was the ability to "set weekly lineups" on-chain. (Most of the gaming component used web2 applications...and web3 component stored the assets, stats and results week by week)
Would your solution allow players to assign tokens they hold (hopefully nested under their primary NFT) in a "lineup"...aka Featured tokens... and have that displayed on a page like this?

One of the struggles that we had last year was the ability to "set weekly lineups" on-chain. (Most of the gaming component used web2 applications...and web3 component stored the assets, stats and results week by week)

messages.text: Hey, thanks! We are using an offchain storage solution (Ceramic Network) to save the information about what things are set to "featured / equipped". It's better than a centralized API in that we don't store the data and the NFT owner has control over what is displayed but still not quite an on-chain solution. Sounds possible though? What's the reason for needing the lineups on chain?

text:
Hi all! I was hoping to clarify the Minimal Proxy gas saving component one more time:)

From my understanding 

In the registry contract:

enables us to create a new proxy for an implementation

So for example: Let's say I have a TBAGameWalletImpl contract which has a simple logic of executeCall() and lock() for a wallet for my specific game.

Now when I call createAccount() on the registry that creates one account for one specific NFT tokenId holder. In other words

B
--owns---> C
--delegatecall--> T

logic 

What I am having a hard time wrapping my head around is the createAccount()

When this is called from the registry does it create a new proxy for the TBAGameWallet? So in other words after a second call to createAccount() from the registry we will now have

BenNFT (id: 1) --owns---> Cheap Proxy --delegatecall--> TBAGameWalletImpl logic
BenNFT (id: 1) --owns---> Cheap Proxy2 --delegatecall--> TBAGameWalletImpl logic

So the benefit of the clone is that it gives us a proxy wallet for a specific NFT for a specific TBA implementation?

If this is correct^ In what scenario would I want to have two proxies for the same NFT tokenId for the same GameWallet TBA implementation.

Thanks for the help!!

text_entities.text:
Hi all! I was hoping to clarify the Minimal Proxy gas saving component one more time:)

From my understanding 

In the registry contract:
createAccount()

enables us to create a new proxy for an implementation

So for example: Let's say I have a TBAGameWalletImpl contract which has a simple logic of executeCall() and lock() for a wallet for my specific game.

Now when I call createAccount() on the registry that creates one account for one specific NFT tokenId holder. In other words

B
enNFT (id: 1)
--owns---> C
heap Proxy
--delegatecall--> T
BAGameWalletImpl

logic 

What I am having a hard time wrapping my head around is the createAccount()

When this is called from the registry does it create a new proxy for the TBAGameWallet? So in other words after a second call to createAccount() from the registry we will now have

BenNFT (id: 1) --owns---> Cheap Proxy --delegatecall--> TBAGameWalletImpl logic
BenNFT (id: 1) --owns---> Cheap Proxy2 --delegatecall--> TBAGameWalletImpl logic

So the benefit of the clone is that it gives us a proxy wallet for a specific NFT for a specific TBA implementation?

If this is correct^ In what scenario would I want to have two proxies for the same NFT tokenId for the same GameWallet TBA implementation.

Thanks for the help!!

messages.text: Happy to clarify^ if my question is unclear thanks again

messages.text: If you are attempting to create an account with the same token parameters (chainId, contract address, tokenId) and registry + account contracts, it should revert because it will produce the same address with create2 that already exists. You can deploy multiple TBA’s for a given token if you switch up the account or registry address being used. Does that answer your question?

text_entities.text: If you are attempting to create an account with the same token parameters (chainId, contract address, tokenId) and registry + account contracts, it should revert because it will produce the same address with create2 that already exists. You can deploy multiple TBA’s for a given token if you switch up the account or registry address being used. Does that answer your question?

messages.text:
Hey guys! Looking forward to the call later on.
Few questions to toss out there...since I'm running a series of tests.

When a TBA is spun up...are you limited to the tokenbound interface in order to manage the assets nested under it?

The new wallet address appears on OpenSea (for example), however does not show any tokens in the wallet ... and I would assume that it is stashed in the HIDDEN folder.
Without "ownership" of that TBA Wallet, it is unable to be managed.

Also, would the nested tokens ONLY appear in the TBA wallet? ... or would they appear in the wallet holding the TBA token as well?

text: Hey

... really bummed I couldn't make the call last night.
I have been running a series of tests and have a few questions to throw out there.
(I'm hopeful to be on the next call so we can chat about it). In the meantime, any insights on this would be helpful.

When a TBA is spun up...are you limited to the tokenbound interface in order to manage the assets nested under it?
In running a test of dynamic metadata & art modifications, it appears the interface is not picking up the changes on chain.

The new wallet address appears on OpenSea (for example), however does not show any tokens in the wallet ... and I would assume that it is stashed in the HIDDEN folder.
Without "ownership" of that TBA Wallet, it is unable to be managed.

Also, would the nested tokens ONLY appear in the TBA wallet? ... or would they appear in the wallet holding the TBA token as well?

text: 1. Nope, you are not limited to
but that is the place to go as we are going to be updating it to be more dynamic. Think of

as a visual etherscan. However, anyone can use the SDK and build their own client if they choose so.

2. Yes, we are aware that the current

doesn't display nesting easily. You can double check the nesting by navigating the URLs but the reason for this is because we feel like it will quickly get confusing for most folks. Rest assured the TBAs can nest infinitely and we will soon be updating the website to display the token graph

3. Dynamic metadata and art modification using the animation URL

within Opensea is something you'll have to build. It depends on how you are fetching the assets within an TBA and then displaying it. That stack is entirely up to you, in the future we will be offering an UI Kit that can help display a standard TBA inventory bar for any projects

4. If you check etherscan the tokens will be in the TBAs. Sometimes Opensea hides new tokens be default. We will soon have the ability ot connect as your NFT so then you can change settings within each TBA account on Opensea. 

5. Not sure about this question around nested tokens. If you put an NFT inside of an NFT. The nested NFT will be owned by the TBA above it.

text_entities.text: 1. Nope, you are not limited to
tokenbound.org
but that is the place to go as we are going to be updating it to be more dynamic. Think of
tokenbound.org

as a visual etherscan. However, anyone can use the SDK and build their own client if they choose so.

2. Yes, we are aware that the current
tokenbound.org

doesn't display nesting easily. You can double check the nesting by navigating the URLs but the reason for this is because we feel like it will quickly get confusing for most folks. Rest assured the TBAs can nest infinitely and we will soon be updating the website to display the token graph

3. Dynamic metadata and art modification using the animation URL
/iframe

within Opensea is something you'll have to build. It depends on how you are fetching the assets within an TBA and then displaying it. That stack is entirely up to you, in the future we will be offering an UI Kit that can help display a standard TBA inventory bar for any projects

4. If you check etherscan the tokens will be in the TBAs. Sometimes Opensea hides new tokens be default. We will soon have the ability ot connect as your NFT so then you can change settings within each TBA account on Opensea. 

5. Not sure about this question around nested tokens. If you put an NFT inside of an NFT. The nested NFT will be owned by the TBA above it.

messages.text:
Awesome! Really appreciate the detailed response.
I've already floated the idea to our inner circle, which consists of several projects ranging from sports to PFPs to gamification to blue-chips.
Ppl's minds are literally exploding with various use cases on this.

Definitely will continue the testing on my end, and happy to work directly with you guys in troubleshooting some of these items as they pop up!

To clarify the last question...The nested NFTs will not longer appear in the user's wallet (since they are now in the TBA) ... even though the TBA's token is in the user's wallet ... correct?

messages.text:
This is interesting! This introduces a new definition floor price of a collection — its no longer just about the demand for the collection but also assets value in the wallet.

I wonder if in this world, we could still differentiate between the demand for the NFT itself and the demand for the NFT + assets & how the norms around asset ownership would form in local economies.

messages.text: Think one of the most interesting identity impacts of 6551 is transferrable identity. Right now identity is tied to a single account, and there are few (if any) ways to trustlessly transfer an account to another person. 6551 allows identities to be transferred / sold via existing NFT marketplace infrastructure. This also has interesting privacy implications. If you put an NFT into an Aztec-style privacy pool, then you still control the account and the associated identity, but the true owner of the account is obscured. Similar privacy elements can be introduced by combining 6551 accounts with stealth addresses

text_entities.text: Think one of the most interesting identity impacts of 6551 is transferrable identity. Right now identity is tied to a single account, and there are few (if any) ways to trustlessly transfer an account to another person. 6551 allows identities to be transferred / sold via existing NFT marketplace infrastructure. This also has interesting privacy implications. If you put an NFT into an Aztec-style privacy pool, then you still control the account and the associated identity, but the true owner of the account is obscured. Similar privacy elements can be introduced by combining 6551 accounts with stealth addresses

messages.text: Adding a restriction to only allow the owner to deploy the account won't solve the issue of spam airdrops. Spam is pretty much impossible to solve on-chain, has to be solved at the client layer imo. The account for an NFT already exists even before the contract is deployed (since all addresses are deterministic), so anyone can airdrop to it before the account is deployed

text_entities.text: Adding a restriction to only allow the owner to deploy the account won't solve the issue of spam airdrops. Spam is pretty much impossible to solve on-chain, has to be solved at the client layer imo. The account for an NFT already exists even before the contract is deployed (since all addresses are deterministic), so anyone can airdrop to it before the account is deployed

messages.text: It's kind of like the early system of Keep3r Network back in 2020. Devs would be rewarded for executing smart contract functions by paying gas and in return execute the "claim" functions for some of the defi protocols and earn a token. The NPC could automate that task by scouting "tasks" and owners are able to tweak parameter scripts to have whitelisted tasks, strategy settings, & literally be your own little worker scanning the blockchain.

text_entities.text: It's kind of like the early system of Keep3r Network back in 2020. Devs would be rewarded for executing smart contract functions by paying gas and in return execute the "claim" functions for some of the defi protocols and earn a token. The NPC could automate that task by scouting "tasks" and owners are able to tweak parameter scripts to have whitelisted tasks, strategy settings, & literally be your own little worker scanning the blockchain.

Hi all, I have some tech implementation questions, well rather I need someone to confirm if my assumptions are correct and If I am missing something here. So.

address .  I can use the already provided implementation that was deployed by tokenbound guys or provide my own?

text_entities.text:
Hi all, I have some tech implementation questions, well rather I need someone to confirm if my assumptions are correct and If I am missing something here. So.

1. The main thing I can change when calling createAccount on deployed ERC6551Registry is
implementation

address .  I can use the already provided implementation that was deployed by tokenbound guys or provide my own?

2. Default implementation is proxy contract but is in control of tokenbound guys and will change depending on them. If I want to have my own implementation I need to build it as a regular contract or proxied contract that I can change?

text:
1. Yep! You can use any implementation you'd like to
2. We don't control the proxy, it's user upgradable. We can't push updates, but account owner can opt into updates if they would like. You can build your own implementation as a regular contract or as an upgradable proxy :)

text_entities.text: @cardinal_error

1. Yep! You can use any implementation you'd like to
2. We don't control the proxy, it's user upgradable. We can't push updates, but account owner can opt into updates if they would like. You can build your own implementation as a regular contract or as an upgradable proxy :)

messages.text: On a side note - something about EIP6551 bothers me - the TCR. Everything else is really suited to membrane computing which is highly composable. The lookup table element is kind of the only clunky element. I guess you could make each ERC6551 have a TCR of its own as just a sort of necessary evil… but then if you wanted to, you could index those using the graph or store them also in a TCr

messages.text: You can lookup the account address for an NFT and send assets to it before it is created. We didn't deploy accounts for each NFT during mint, we only sent assets there. Sapienz holders can deploy the account for their NFT at any time and access the assets. So yes - you can nest things "virtually" thanks to the deterministic nature of 6551 addresses :)

messages.text: Every NFT is compatible with 6551, so you can choose how you would like to allow users to mint within the 721 contract. It's definitely possible to use 6551 in your mint logic by sending assets to an NFTs account address.

text: Pleasure to be here. I'm founder of unbond - we started building NFT based accounts last year (our testnet is at

) . Our flow is we allow you to mint a new NFT vault and let that vault own various different assets and we also offer wallet connectivity so that NFT vault can interact with various DApps. I was pleased to hear about TokenBound accounts because that's very similar to what we are building and only strengthens our thesis.

text_entities.text: Pleasure to be here. I'm founder of unbond - we started building NFT based accounts last year (our testnet is at
https://unbond.vercel.app/

) . Our flow is we allow you to mint a new NFT vault and let that vault own various different assets and we also offer wallet connectivity so that NFT vault can interact with various DApps. I was pleased to hear about TokenBound accounts because that's very similar to what we are building and only strengthens our thesis.

text:
Been working on this for half a year now but only when there was a release of 6551 did this thing finally get a good fit.
So with my team, I am building one of the first TBA projects in this space, aimed more at the general population with elements of education, fun, and memes.
We plan to launch the base TBA NFT token sometime during next week and then run a series of other drops to TBA holders so they can get the full experience of the features this token standard will bring.
As the TBA is mostly about managing your assets and identity we bring you "The Managers" :) which should be a nice fit for that and broader adoption.
Hope you can like and RT our project and help us spread the word

text_entities.text:
Been working on this for half a year now but only when there was a release of 6551 did this thing finally get a good fit.
So with my team, I am building one of the first TBA projects in this space, aimed more at the general population with elements of education, fun, and memes.
We plan to launch the base TBA NFT token sometime during next week and then run a series of other drops to TBA holders so they can get the full experience of the features this token standard will bring.
As the TBA is mostly about managing your assets and identity we bring you "The Managers" :) which should be a nice fit for that and broader adoption.
Hope you can like and RT our project and help us spread the word
https://themanagers.wtf/

text:
Welcome everyone that is new to the community I'll just reshare the pinned post so everyone is aware!

--

1. Everyone here is a builder and actively providing opinions or contributing to the open source standard

2. We'll try to keep memes to a minimum and will enforce if it gets too out of hands. The purpose of this group is to build together and to share work or ask questions about ERC 6551

3. We have weekly dev/design calls on Thursdays
4. At any time, we encourage people to share their MVPs or projects using ERC 6551/TBAs. Mint your ERC 6551 membership NFT powered by 0xStation as a fun experiment

5. We're here to rally the community towards making NFTs an awesome thing to own and collect. We mostly come from a development perspective rather than a shilling one, so please be mindful of that

6. The biggest contribuition you can make to this open standard is to share your feedback here:
7. If you have any issues with the SDK

or with anything feel free to share your questions in this group

8. Be nice. Be friendly. Be helpful to each other. No harrassment is tolerated and will be removed immediately. 

9. All constructive ideas are welcomed and we encourage healthy debates. We are aware that the NFT ecosystem is huge and there are so many projects that have different use cases. ERC 6551 is designed to be flexible, composable, and open so that anyone can customize it as they see fit.

10. When referencing ERC 6551 we usually call them Token Bound Accounts (TBAs). That is the most technically correct term.

text_entities.text:
Welcome everyone that is new to the community I'll just reshare the pinned post so everyone is aware!

--

1. Everyone here is a builder and actively providing opinions or contributing to the open source standard

2. We'll try to keep memes to a minimum and will enforce if it gets too out of hands. The purpose of this group is to build together and to share work or ask questions about ERC 6551

3. We have weekly dev/design calls on Thursdays
https://calendar.google.com/calendar/u/1/r?cid=Y185OTNjZmNjOGRjNWE5MDdlM2Y1N2M4YWI0NTQwYzRiMTVhNTQ4ODc2YmQ0OWMyMWEwYmExY2RkMGU2MDE4ZjVhQGdyb3VwLmNhbGVuZGFyLmdvb2dsZS5jb20
4. At any time, we encourage people to share their MVPs or projects using ERC 6551/TBAs. Mint your ERC 6551 membership NFT powered by 0xStation as a fun experiment
https://members.station.express/matic:0x10e0ad62eef221ea562a9d5db80c25629c419d15/directory

5. We're here to rally the community towards making NFTs an awesome thing to own and collect. We mostly come from a development perspective rather than a shilling one, so please be mindful of that

6. The biggest contribuition you can make to this open standard is to share your feedback here:
https://ethereum-magicians.org/t/erc-6551-non-fungible-token-bound-accounts/13030
7. If you have any issues with the SDK
https://docs.tokenbound.org/

or with anything feel free to share your questions in this group

8. Be nice. Be friendly. Be helpful to each other. No harrassment is tolerated and will be removed immediately. 

9. All constructive ideas are welcomed and we encourage healthy debates. We are aware that the NFT ecosystem is huge and there are so many projects that have different use cases. ERC 6551 is designed to be flexible, composable, and open so that anyone can customize it as they see fit.

10. When referencing ERC 6551 we usually call them Token Bound Accounts (TBAs). That is the most technically correct term.

text: Hey

thanks for the add in here! So we have spent a good time developing an NFT that acts as a portfolio and houses tokens only what you guys have built is next level and im very impressed! 

What we built and is currently live with our collection of NFTs is being able to display the tokens that are “held” by that NFT live on the metadata and on opensea in the attributes section. Ideally the goal for us was to also turn the NFTS into wallet addresses and not just that we have plans for other things but id love to test how we can use erc6551 and we will playing around with them! Thanks Benny for the add!
