messages.text: gm all. Quick question regarding delegation, consolidation and ERC6551. How would delegation work in the instance of a nested NFT within a wallet with minting Delegation? Would the NFTs wallet need to assign delegation separately or would it follow same rules as parent wallet?

text_entities.text: gm all. Quick question regarding delegation, consolidation and ERC6551. How would delegation work in the instance of a nested NFT within a wallet with minting Delegation? Would the NFTs wallet need to assign delegation separately or would it follow same rules as parent wallet?

messages.text: Non dev asking

text_entities.text: Non dev asking

messages.text:
Depends if it’s one wallet or multiple. If it’s one, one delegation. If it’s multiple, then it’s multiple.  Even if it’s nested, the ownership doesn’t change. 

For example, you own 10 wallets through your Nft. Each wallet is still separate but still controlled by 1 erc-721.

text_entities.text:
Depends if it’s one wallet or multiple. If it’s one, one delegation. If it’s multiple, then it’s multiple.  Even if it’s nested, the ownership doesn’t change. 

For example, you own 10 wallets through your Nft. Each wallet is still separate but still controlled by 1 erc-721.

messages.text: Think of it as sub accounts in one private key

text_entities.text: Think of it as sub accounts in one private key

messages.text: So delegation for erc721 would also apply to the 6551s within it?

text_entities.text: So delegation for erc721 would also apply to the 6551s within it?

messages.text: Same should apply for consolidations also?

text_entities.text: Same should apply for consolidations also?

messages.text:
If you delegate ownership of it then yes, you don’t own true execution rights. 

Think of it as a company. You sell 51% of it. You’re no longer in control. 

In this instance, if you fractionalize, it’s not technically the NFT that holds the value because it’s a derivative of the original owner.( original 721.)

text_entities.text:
If you delegate ownership of it then yes, you don’t own true execution rights. 

Think of it as a company. You sell 51% of it. You’re no longer in control. 

In this instance, if you fractionalize, it’s not technically the NFT that holds the value because it’s a derivative of the original owner.( original 721.)

text: Thanks

, appreciate the feedback.
I agree on both points and had actually considered both before creating the extension. 

There's two things we are trying to solve for, and there's likely a better way to do it.

#1 we don't want our users to ever have to use their cold wallets (signature or otherwise) in order to create / manage an account.

#2 We don't want to introduce any new concepts/would like to leverage a solution that already exists. We are catering specifically to the Yuga community which are all aware/familiar with using delegate/warm already.

messages.text:
fractionalized ownership of the key. It's basically a full vote multi-sig if fractionalized but if one signer doesn't agree, it doesn't complete the full conversion to sign. 

Use cases:
hierarchy governance. Founders have to all sign on a unanimous decision for their business spend. If a founder exits after vesting period but others want to still continue, they can still sell their fractionalized key to another investor to take over governance of the vote.

fractionalized ownership of the key. It's basically a full vote multi-sig if fractionalized but if one signer doesn't agree, it doesn't complete the full conversion to sign. 

Use cases:
hierarchy governance. Founders have to all sign on a unanimous decision for their business spend. If a founder exits after vesting period but others want to still continue, they can still sell their fractionalized key to another investor to take over governance of the vote.

messages.text: Hey there! Happy to be here. I am just getting started with TBAs and I’m still grabbing my mind around it. What are the best resources to learn more apart from the docs and GitHub? Also, one question I have is what would be the best way to have multiple people own an account? messages.text: I'll ask ahead of someone responding. I'm looking to carry out an airdrop to holders of a specific collection. Around 1000 NFTs within the collection in total. The idea is to airdrop a token to a tokenbound wallet for each piece in the collection. I've just had a look at wallet addys to check if they would be sequential (making compiling a list easier) and it doesn't look like they are. How would I go about creating a list of tokenbound wallet addresses for a collection this size? I'll also add that I'm not a developer or a coder.

text_entities.text: I'll ask ahead of someone responding. I'm looking to carry out an airdrop to holders of a specific collection. Around 1000 NFTs within the collection in total. The idea is to airdrop a token to a tokenbound wallet for each piece in the collection. I've just had a look at wallet addys to check if they would be sequential (making compiling a list easier) and it doesn't look like they are. How would I go about creating a list of tokenbound wallet addresses for a collection this size? I'll also add that I'm not a developer or a coder.

messages.text: You'll probably need help from a developer here. The account addresses aren't sequention, you'll need to do is calculate the account addresses for each of the 1k NFTs and then send the tokens to those addresses using a multisender.

text_entities.text: You'll probably need help from a developer here. The account addresses aren't sequention, you'll need to do is calculate the account addresses for each of the 1k NFTs and then send the tokens to those addresses using a multisender.

messages.text:
Hey everyone! Kelly (Dev Evangelist) from Pinata 👋 We started from the beginning of NFTs and we're still here coz we genuinely believe that they are the future 😎 We're super duuuuuper excited about all things ERC-6551 and want to be loud proponents of its development 🔥

I wanted to introduce myself and put out in the open a few items 💜:
1️⃣ I've been working on creating content on TBAs, with plans to push all live by June 30th. Will share any roadblocks, learnings and questions here 👍
2️⃣ Continuing on the convo regarding IRL meetups from today's dev call -- Is anyone going to be at ETH Barcelona 🇪🇸 July 5-9th? Would love to collaborate on hosting an IRL gathering for peeps in the community 😎
3️⃣ On another note, we'd be down to host/support Twitter Spaces, webinars, online discussions and more to educate the community. Feel free to DM me if you'd be keen to make something happen 🤩

text_entities.text: Hi guys! i am interested in using ERC-6551, love the stuff being built. I was wondering if there's ways to attach a token, that if by itself cannot sold... but only can be sold with the erc721 its attatched to. So its bound to the erc721 and cannot be sold seperately.

messages.text:
Hi guys! great to be here. 

I have been studying 6551 and encountered some questions! if anyone has answers, thanks in advance 🙏

Situation : 
Let's say in a web3 game, user minted Avatar NFT and one has deployed the contract to activate(?) this Avatar NFT as TBA. he/she achieved top player badge which is also NFT. 
Let's say this badge NFT goes under Avatar NFT (which means Avatar NFT TBA owns this badge NFT)
And after a while, user wants to sell this badge NFT in Opensea.
 
Q. theoretically, user needs to connect Avatar NFT TBA to Opensea? but how would it be possible?

Q. Only tokens of the same chain with Avatar NFT TBA can be sent to this TBA right?

text_entities.text:

messages.text:
Good questions!
- Pretty soon you'll be able to connect your NFT's account directly to OpenSea using walletconnect
- it depends on the implementation you use and whether it supports cross-chain accounts. The implementation we've built will support NFTs on one chain owning assets using the same token bound account address on another chain

UPDATES from the weekly dev call:

- ERC 6551 is live on polygon, gnosis chain, optimism, arbitrum, mumbai testnet, goerli, sepolia

- Wallet connect integration work in progress

- New

V1.5 update shipping soon

- New embedded account viewer V1.5 (iframe) update coming soon. Will be usable by other projects.

- New community page if you are working on a project using ERC 6551 submit it here

- ERC 6551 bundler coming soon!

Lastly! Congrats on winning a prize at ETHPrague with your project

text: This has been previously asked. There are no plans for this.

is primarily intended for read permissions, not write delegation. 

If you delegate writes of an nft wallet there would need to be a mechanism to invalidate those write upon nft transfer otherwise it opens up a pretty big security vulnerability.

text_entities.text: This has been previously asked. There are no plans for this.
Delegate.cash

is primarily intended for read permissions, not write delegation. 

If you delegate writes of an nft wallet there would need to be a mechanism to invalidate those write upon nft transfer otherwise it opens up a pretty big security vulnerability.

messages.text: Nothing prevents a custom 6551 implementation from allowing this, but the reference implementation doesn’t have this feature.

text_entities.text: Nothing prevents a custom 6551 implementation from allowing this, but the reference implementation doesn’t have this feature.

messages.text: This security issue seems like it would only apply if the token bound account was creating delegations. I think an implementation could read the current token owner's existing delegations from the delegation registry and use that to authorize execution on the account without any security issues.

text_entities.text: This security issue seems like it would only apply if the token bound account was creating delegations. I think an implementation could read the current token owner's existing delegations from the delegation registry and use that to authorize execution on the account without any security issues.

text: Well, I would still say this isn’t a good idea because it’s unexpected behavior with
and the marketplace. Ppl selling delegations so ppl can claim airdrops for example. If they did this they wouldn’t expect that person to also be able to transfer out assets.

text_entities.text: Well, I would still say this isn’t a good idea because it’s unexpected behavior with

messages.text:
So currently that’s a centralized system. We have a server that allows you to equip gear and we save a mapping of it on our end. Then our rendering engine spits the layer orders with gear for the sapienz.

Saving that data right now on chain is expensive for the user and slow.

TBA helps us know what gear is owned by the sapienz so it saves a ton of centralized work we would’ve had to do there. We can leverage existing indexers to help us out instead. 

Maybe in the near future, there will be a cheaper way to save that data mapping on chain. Would love to hear any ideas on that if you got something cooking!

messages.text: There are pros and cons to equipping as an on-chain association. Gas would be the biggest concern. There are ways that I have implemented and seen that at least create a nice mapping from "item" -> storage slot represented by a subset of bits in a uint256 to represent each group and each layer but this would not work for a generic erc721 implementation.

messages.text: I'd like to know a little more how the transactions would work for my members on my platform if I was to use 6551. I'm trying to attract web2 users to our platform and want to keep signatures for transactions to an absolute minimum. So my question is if our NFT is 6551 and is being held by a master wallet then how will transactions be authorized and if this NFT is nesting other NFTs then how will the transaction count be minimized?

text_entities.text: I'd like to know a little more how the transactions would work for my members on my platform if I was to use 6551. I'm trying to attract web2 users to our platform and want to keep signatures for transactions to an absolute minimum. So my question is if our NFT is 6551 and is being held by a master wallet then how will transactions be authorized and if this NFT is nesting other NFTs then how will the transaction count be minimized?

messages.text:
I understand the addresses are computed in a deterministic manner but, the account itself should only be created when the function to create an account in the registry is called right?

The ability to execute request is only available once the function in the registry is called to create the account as far as i understand. 

So like my question would be, how can i tell apart if an NFT has the proxy deployed or not, and which address was asigned to it?

Thanks for the help.

text_entities.text:
I understand the addresses are computed in a deterministic manner but, the account itself should only be created when the function to create an account in the registry is called right?

The ability to execute request is only available once the function in the registry is called to create the account as far as i understand. 

So like my question would be, how can i tell apart if an NFT has the proxy deployed or not, and which address was asigned to it?

Thanks for the help.

messages.text: This is correct. The address assigned to an NFT is static and reserved for that NFT. So the NFT's address can receive assets prior to deployment. You can tell if the proxy is deployed or not by checking the bytecode size at the NFT's account address

text_entities.text: This is correct. The address assigned to an NFT is static and reserved for that NFT. So the NFT's address can receive assets prior to deployment. You can tell if the proxy is deployed or not by checking the bytecode size at the NFT's account address

messages.text: Yep, 6551 largely treats NFTs as tied to their native chain. Bridging NFTs to a new chain will give you a new account address since it will have a different contract address and token id. Instead of bridging the asset, implementations can use a bridge to execute cross chain calls while the NFT stays on one chain

Bridging NFTs to a new chain will give you a new account address since it will have a different contract address and token id. Instead of bridging the asset, implementations can use a bridge to execute cross chain calls while the NFT stays on one chain

text:
Hey everyone, just posting again about how to use the tokenbound iframe in your NFT projects. There’s two ways you can interact with the iframe. 

Easiest way is to use our hosted iframe here:
. For example if you want to see this for an Azuki with a tokenId of 108, then this would be the iframe url:

. This works great for existing NFT collections as we leverage alchemy’s indexer to fetch your nft metadata attributes for the image. You could do this for a new NFT collection as well, however you might have to wait a little for alchemy to cache your collection metadata. 

If you’re looking to host your own iframe, then we have a repo you can fork here:

. You’ll need to uncomment some code and set some environment variables to get this working. Feel free to DM me here so I can go through it with you. I didn’t get a chance to make it easier to integrate as the current iframe is built to run the implementation above. I will update the this repo to make it easier to integrate for custom implementation later this week.

However for now I suggest going with the first implementation.

text_entities.text:
Hey everyone, just posting again about how to use the tokenbound iframe in your NFT projects. There’s two ways you can interact with the iframe. 

Easiest way is to use our hosted iframe here:
https://iframe-tokenbound.vercel.app/<contractAddress>/<tokenId>
. For example if you want to see this for an Azuki with a tokenId of 108, then this would be the iframe url:
https://iframe-tokenbound.vercel.app/0xed5af388653567af2f388e6224dc7c4b3241c544/108

. This works great for existing NFT collections as we leverage alchemy’s indexer to fetch your nft metadata attributes for the image. You could do this for a new NFT collection as well, however you might have to wait a little for alchemy to cache your collection metadata. 

If you’re looking to host your own iframe, then we have a repo you can fork here:
https://github.com/tokenbound/iframe

. You’ll need to uncomment some code and set some environment variables to get this working. Feel free to DM me here so I can go through it with you. I didn’t get a chance to make it easier to integrate as the current iframe is built to run the implementation above. I will update the this repo to make it easier to integrate for custom implementation later this week.

However for now I suggest going with the first implementation.

text_entities.text:
Hello everyone!

I am reading the docs but I do not get something clear. Let's say I already created the token bound account of a nft I own, then I send a new nft to the token bound account; is there a way to send this new nft to another address? Using prepareExecuteCall or executeCall? 

Thanks beforehand 🫡😁

messages.text:
Yes, If I am not wrong, you can call executeCall with the "to" as the new NFT's address, "value" as the amount of ETH you want to send with this call(in this case it'll be 0) and data as the abi encoded calldata of the safeTransfer function and it's arguments.

Someone please correct me if I'm wrong.

Someone please correct me if I'm wrong.

messages.text: Great question! This is something we're still working on building out. Essentially, each NFT gets the same address across all chains that ERC-6551 exists on. If the implementation supports cross-chain calls via a bridge, the NFT owner can execute transactions using their token bound account on other chains. In this case, transferring the mainnet NFT would bring the polygon (and any other chain) assets with it.

text_entities.text: Great question! This is something we're still working on building out. Essentially, each NFT gets the same address across all chains that ERC-6551 exists on. If the implementation supports cross-chain calls via a bridge, the NFT owner can execute transactions using their token bound account on other chains. In this case, transferring the mainnet NFT would bring the polygon (and any other chain) assets with it.

text: Hey

thanks for the chat yesterday. Wanted to throw out the question here that we were discussing:

Afaik all existing 721s have a token bound address that can be found through the registry. All new 721s that are being dropped now are continuing to get token bound addresses that are being added to the registry -- is that right?

If that is right, and the registry is fully onchain, who is paying gas to update the registry with this new information and how does that process work?

messages.text:
Because deployed contracts across chains aren't the same.

Deploying nft A on ethereum and then on polygon doesn't mean they have the same contract address on both chains. 

So if project A has deployed Nft A to ethereum and polygon and their Contract addresses are different (which they will be) than the bridged in assets (those assets your saying maintain their address as a holder address across evm chains)
Would have a different contract address than their official counterparts on the bridged in chain.

text_entities.text:
Because deployed contracts across chains aren't the same.

Deploying nft A on ethereum and then on polygon doesn't mean they have the same contract address on both chains. 

So if project A has deployed Nft A to ethereum and polygon and their Contract addresses are different (which they will be) than the bridged in assets (those assets your saying maintain their address as a holder address across evm chains)
Would have a different contract address than their official counterparts on the bridged in chain.

messages.text: Ah I see! In this case, the NFT contract should only exist on one chain (unless you're using something with built-in briding like layerzero's omni nft in which case you will have the same address across chains). Even though the NFT contract only exists on a single chain, the NFT has a token bound account address that exists on all chains

text_entities.text: Ah I see! In this case, the NFT contract should only exist on one chain (unless you're using something with built-in briding like layerzero's omni nft in which case you will have the same address across chains). Even though the NFT contract only exists on a single chain, the NFT has a token bound account address that exists on all chains

quick question, and sorry if it's a silly one:

i'd like to write a contract that when the mint() function is called, it actually mints 5 NFTs - 1 "parent" NFT that then owns 4 "child" NFTs

the parent smart contract would send 2 data points to the child nfts that would be used in their mint function for their metadata and on-chain svg ("position" and "colour")

so wondering if this is possible rn? the parent NFT would be the 6551, and its animation_url would display the 4 children in a specific layout (not the Sapienz tab method)

if it is, I'll just push ahead with my r&d and get building :)

messages.text: This is definitely possible! You can compute the account address for the NFT you're minting within the mint function, and have a custom iframe that handles querying of the metadata for the NFTs within the account :)

text:
After taking a deeper look, the Registry seems to be public, but not the implementation. 

I've only found that the already deployed not only doesn't match with the one on the EIP or the

, but it is also upgradeable. The one who is able to upgrade is the current token owner, not the base implementation that everyone clones, right? But only to a list of trusted implementations defined by the "guardian". Is that interpretation correct? I haven't been able to take a proper deep look at the code.

Also, if the entry point and guardians are not the same on every EVM we won't have the same final implementation addresses. Right?

However, I've seen nobody talking about this, but I see this relevant.

Am I missing anything?

text_entities.text:
After taking a deeper look, the Registry seems to be public, but not the implementation. 

I've only found that the already deployed not only doesn't match with the one on the EIP or the
https://github.com/erc6551/reference/

, but it is also upgradeable. The one who is able to upgrade is the current token owner, not the base implementation that everyone clones, right? But only to a list of trusted implementations defined by the "guardian". Is that interpretation correct? I haven't been able to take a proper deep look at the code.

Also, if the entry point and guardians are not the same on every EVM we won't have the same final implementation addresses. Right?

However, I've seen nobody talking about this, but I see this relevant.

Am I missing anything?

text: Great questions! The implementation is public, you can find it here:

Correct - only the owner can upgrade an account, and they can only upgrade to a trusted implement to prevent against bricking an account for other holders.

Also correct re: addresses, however the guardian and entry point are deployed to the same address on each chain.

text_entities.text: Great questions! The implementation is public, you can find it here:
https://github.com/tokenbound/contracts/blob/jw/account-v2/src/Account.sol

Correct - only the owner can upgrade an account, and they can only upgrade to a trusted implement to prevent against bricking an account for other holders.

Also correct re: addresses, however the guardian and entry point are deployed to the same address on each chain.

messages.text:
So..., after taking another look, there is no chance to replicate on other network the implementation because we don't have the private key from 0x0B36FcE76b3941571a547939B8fbAc2C39F84696, which is the deployer of "AccountGuardian". Since it is not using the Nicks methods, the only way to get that creation address is having the PK from 0x0B36FcE76b3941571a547939B8fbAc2C39F84696. And if the  "AccountGuardian" address is not the same, when creating the account implementation (0x1a0e97dae78590b7e967e725a5c848ed034f5510) the code will differ and so the final given address. So we are stuck and can't deploy with the same implementation address.

For a standard, this shouldn't be done this way, as we won't be able to deploy on not "officially" supported, and we will depend on the owner of that account to share the same address multi-chain.

text_entities.text:
So..., after taking another look, there is no chance to replicate on other network the implementation because we don't have the private key from 0x0B36FcE76b3941571a547939B8fbAc2C39F84696, which is the deployer of "AccountGuardian". Since it is not using the Nicks methods, the only way to get that creation address is having the PK from 0x0B36FcE76b3941571a547939B8fbAc2C39F84696. And if the  "AccountGuardian" address is not the same, when creating the account implementation (0x1a0e97dae78590b7e967e725a5c848ed034f5510) the code will differ and so the final given address. So we are stuck and can't deploy with the same implementation address.

For a standard, this shouldn't be done this way, as we won't be able to deploy on not "officially" supported, and we will depend on the owner of that account to share the same address multi-chain.

messages.text:
Hey folks, my team plans on using 6551 to create programmatic PFPs. Our main idea involves exposing a public tokenURI() method on Account.sol, which modifies the underlying 721's tokenURI with some custom logic. 

Will this potentially conflict with how tokenURIs are being retrieved for 6551 tokens? (not too sure if there's another way to retrieve it other than from the underlying 721's tokenURI). 
Also, were there any prior discussion on including a public tokenURI() method in the EIP? Am interested be find out more about this thank you! 🙌

messages.text: working on an inventory system of sorts, looking to know what rules can be imposed on token bound wallets (e.g. certain item types), and where these rules are defined

text_entities.text: working on an inventory system of sorts, looking to know what rules can be imposed on token bound wallets (e.g. certain item types), and where these rules are defined

text.text: Here are my questions so far:

text:
1) What kind of rules can be imposed on accounts? Can certain NFTs be whitelisted? What about on-chain properties as filters?
2) Can accounts be created during the mint of an NFT?
3) If I wanted to set up an inventory structure via accounts (e.g. 1 NFT has 4 backpack slots, 1 of each type and each backpack slots can hold a weapon (NFT), each with a number of gem slots), it feels like this could get costly fast. Am I missing something?

text_entities.text: Here are my questions so far:

1) What kind of rules can be imposed on accounts? Can certain NFTs be whitelisted? What about on-chain properties as filters?
2) Can accounts be created during the mint of an NFT?
3) If I wanted to set up an inventory structure via accounts (e.g. 1 NFT has 4 backpack slots, 1 of each type and each backpack slots can hold a weapon (NFT), each with a number of gem slots), it feels like this could get costly fast. Am I missing something?

1) By default accounts are self-soverign (no rules on what can be held). If you want to impose rules that can be done using a custom account implementation
2) Yep!
3) Generally it's best to separate ownership and equipping within your dapp. Ownership is handled by the account, equipping logic should be handled by your game logic contract

messages.text: If the account contract is deployed, the NFT information can be pulled from the bytecode of the account contract. If the account contract is not yet deployed, this data will need to be pulled from an off chain indexer. The registry does not store this data in order to keep deployment gas costs low, as storing in the bytecode of the account is cheaper

Yes you're right, but we wanted to make the tokenURI more customisable, based on the collectables that the Account currently has / some other custom logic.

Of course, this can be done off chain / wrap 721 in some other contract, but we wanted the logic and customization to be on chain. Adding a tokenURI() method to Account is similar to how tokenURI(tokenId) represents the image of a nft token.

text:
Thank you everyone for joining this working group! A few important rules:

1. Everyone here is a builder and actively providing opinions or contributing to the open source standard

2. We'll try to keep memes to a minimum and will enforce if it gets too out of hands. The purpose of this group is to build together and to share work or ask questions about ERC 6551

3. We have weekly dev/design calls on Thursdays
4. At any time, we encourage people to share their MVPs or projects using ERC 6551/TBAs. Mint your ERC 6551 membership NFT powered by 0xStation as a fun experiment

5. We're here to rally the community towards making NFTs an awesome thing to own and collect. We mostly come from a development perspective rather than a shilling one, so please be mindful of that

6. The biggest contribuition you can make to this open standard is to share your feedback here:
7. If you have any issues with the SDK

or with anything feel free to share your questions in this group

8. Be nice. Be friendly. Be helpful to each other. No harrassment is tolerated and will be removed immediately. 

9. All constructive ideas are welcomed and we encourage healthy debates. We are aware that the NFT ecosystem is huge and there are so many projects that have different use cases. ERC 6551 is designed to be flexible, composable, and open so that anyone can customize it as they see fit.

10. When referencing ERC 6551 we usually call them Token Bound Accounts (TBAs). That is the most technically correct term.

11. Submit your project to the community page

text_entities.text:
Thank you everyone for joining this working group! A few important rules:

1. Everyone here is a builder and actively providing opinions or contributing to the open source standard

2. We'll try to keep memes to a minimum and will enforce if it gets too out of hands. The purpose of this group is to build together and to share work or ask questions about ERC 6551

3. We have weekly dev/design calls on Thursdays
https://calendar.google.com/calendar/u/1/r?cid=Y185OTNjZmNjOGRjNWE5MDdlM2Y1N2M4YWI0NTQwYzRiMTVhNTQ4ODc2YmQ0OWMyMWEwYmExY2RkMGU2MDE4ZjVhQGdyb3VwLmNhbGVuZGFyLmdvb2dsZS5jb20
4. At any time, we encourage people to share their MVPs or projects using ERC 6551/TBAs. Mint your ERC 6551 membership NFT powered by 0xStation as a fun experiment
https://members.station.express/matic:0x10e0ad62eef221ea562a9d5db80c25629c419d15/directory

5. We're here to rally the community towards making NFTs an awesome thing to own and collect. We mostly come from a development perspective rather than a shilling one, so please be mindful of that

6. The biggest contribuition you can make to this open standard is to share your feedback here:
https://ethereum-magicians.org/t/erc-6551-non-fungible-token-bound-accounts/13030
7. If you have any issues with the SDK
https://docs.tokenbound.org/

or with anything feel free to share your questions in this group

8. Be nice. Be friendly. Be helpful to each other. No harrassment is tolerated and will be removed immediately. 

9. All constructive ideas are welcomed and we encourage healthy debates. We are aware that the NFT ecosystem is huge and there are so many projects that have different use cases. ERC 6551 is designed to be flexible, composable, and open so that anyone can customize it as they see fit.

10. When referencing ERC 6551 we usually call them Token Bound Accounts (TBAs). That is the most technically correct term.

11. Submit your project to the community page
https://forms.gle/S3c4SQqC6bDK4x9u8

text:
Hi all. Airstack team is thrilled to be part of this working group. We had great experience already with 6551 at ETH Waterloo

We're working on indexing 6551's and providing GraphQL APIs to devs, with first release coming next week

Here's our near term roadmap. 

1. Release 1: 11 July, 2023: Query 6551 account associated with ERC-721 token, along with balances of 6551 account, ens, social etc. AI-engine to write queries  
2. Release 1: 11 July, 2023:  Fetch all 6551 accounts based on timestamps  
3. Release 2: fast follow with Optimistic indexing of 6551 
4. Release 3: Tree traversal:  recursively fetch 6551 accounts 
5. Release 3: Overall worth of 6551 root account - sum of all 6551 account in the tree 
6. Release 4: Cycle detection: To make sure EOA owns 6551 account 

We'll make all this available to everyone as it's released. Feedback and input highly appreciated. The more feedback and inputs the faster we can move to get you what you need/ useful for devs
will join the dev call tomorrow, and we'll be in position to demo/release on the call next week

text_entities.text:
Hi all. Airstack team is thrilled to be part of this working group. We had great experience already with 6551 at ETH Waterloo

We're working on indexing 6551's and providing GraphQL APIs to devs, with first release coming next week

Here's our near term roadmap. 

1. Release 1: 11 July, 2023: Query 6551 account associated with ERC-721 token, along with balances of 6551 account, ens, social etc. AI-engine to write queries  
2. Release 1: 11 July, 2023:  Fetch all 6551 accounts based on timestamps  
3. Release 2: fast follow with Optimistic indexing of 6551 
4. Release 3: Tree traversal:  recursively fetch 6551 accounts 
5. Release 3: Overall worth of 6551 root account - sum of all 6551 account in the tree 
6. Release 4: Cycle detection: To make sure EOA owns 6551 account 

We'll make all this available to everyone as it's released. Feedback and input highly appreciated. The more feedback and inputs the faster we can move to get you what you need/ useful for devs

messages.text:
Hi Colin, we don't have an official subgraph for indexing Tokenbound accounts currently, but the Airstack team is working on an indexer & GraphQL API to make fetching account data and balances much easier! They have posted some info above, looks like an early version will be ready soon! In the meantime, you can use any service you prefer to fetch the balance of any Tokenbound account address as you would a normal EOA wallet. For more complicated or nested queries though, we'll see some developments soon!
Is there a particular set of data or events that you don't have access to right now that would be helpful for what you are building?

text:
We were previously using RainbowKit on early iterations of the Sapienz project but ran into issues with flexibility in modal management. Just a UI grievance, not anything to do with connectivity.

The RainbowKit docs appear to be using a base wagmi config, which aligns with how we do things using ConnectKit. But our example apps aren’t using RainbowKit. We can perhaps work on providing better example coverage for a few more popular wallet implementations.

This comment also made clear that we were not explicitly linking to the SDK example apps on the Tokenbound docs site. That’s rectified now.

The SDK uses viem at its core so using a viem walletClient for signing is definitely most aligned and lightweight, but ethers signers from v5.7+ and v6 are also supported. Each is shown in the apps linked above.

text_entities.text: @sweetman_eth

We were previously using RainbowKit on early iterations of the Sapienz project but ran into issues with flexibility in modal management. Just a UI grievance, not anything to do with connectivity.

The RainbowKit docs appear to be using a base wagmi config, which aligns with how we do things using ConnectKit. But our example apps aren’t using RainbowKit. We can perhaps work on providing better example coverage for a few more popular wallet implementations.

This comment also made clear that we were not explicitly linking to the SDK example apps on the Tokenbound docs site. That’s rectified now.
https://github.com/tokenbound/sdk/tree/main/examples

The SDK uses viem at its core so using a viem walletClient for signing is definitely most aligned and lightweight, but ethers signers from v5.7+ and v6 are also supported. Each is shown in the apps linked above.

messages.text:
curious if anyone is working on something like this:

website tool:
1) connect your wallet
2) mint a "[MyNFT] NFT" to your wallet, where [MyNFT] NFT's image and metadata is its TBA address
3) select tokens from your wallet to send to [MyNFT] (6551)
4) listing all the included tokens in the [MyNFT] metadata would be awesome, if possible

result:  person now has a "wrapped" collection token that can be bought/sold

sample use case:  you've collected all 10 of a 10-piece art series.  rather than "bundling" the sale of the whole series on opensea, you wrap those 10 pieces in your MyNFT and then can action it more simply.  

if this doesn't exist - and someone wants to talk about building it (i'm not a dev 😅)- hit me up.  i think it'd be handy.

text:
would like your opinion on this. Is there some plans to do some kind of state saving in TBA wallet of what it owns. 
Meaning to have some function that shows which tokens from other smart contract the TBA wallet has. 
I believe currently TBA site is using transfer events to determine and show what each TBA is owning? Which is fine for FE.
I do have some ideas to build something more onchain where smart contract should know what it owns. Wondering if I am reinventing the wheel here, probably not?
My idea is then to store that info in Main NFT smart contract from which TBA is derived, Does this make sense or would you do it differently?

messages.text: For some use cases of “cookie”, sure. For example, we have used Urbit ID (erc721) tokens to sign in to one’s remote hosted server with just a signed message from the wallet holding the token that then sets the authentication cookie. But cookies are used for a whole lot of things and for those that don’t require user interaction (contra authentication or similar actions), I suspect the UX limitations would be too constraining.

text_entities.text: For some use cases of “cookie”, sure. For example, we have used Urbit ID (erc721) tokens to sign in to one’s remote hosted server with just a signed message from the wallet holding the token that then sets the authentication cookie. But cookies are used for a whole lot of things and for those that don’t require user interaction (contra authentication or similar actions), I suspect the UX limitations would be too constraining.

messages.text: UX constrained use cases aside, on the Urbit side you would be able to get a lot of privacy/off-chain data benefits that might be compelling to people.

text_entities.text: UX constrained use cases aside, on the Urbit side you would be able to get a lot of privacy/off-chain data benefits that might be compelling to people.

messages.text: Hey everyone, new here, trying to get my head around 6551...suppose I have 3 NFTs, A (parent), B (Child) and C (Child of child). If B gets transferred, A remains intact but C won't be accessible anymore, is this correct? On the contrary, if only C gets transferred, A and B will remain accessible and C will be usable under the new account owner. Please let me know if my understanding is correct, many thanks in advance!

text_entities.text: Hey everyone, new here, trying to get my head around 6551...suppose I have 3 NFTs, A (parent), B (Child) and C (Child of child). If B gets transferred, A remains intact but C won't be accessible anymore, is this correct? On the contrary, if only C gets transferred, A and B will remain accessible and C will be usable under the new account owner. Please let me know if my understanding is correct, many thanks in advance!

messages.text: This is correct - ownership in 6551 accounts is transitive

text_entities.text: This is correct - ownership in 6551 accounts is transitive

messages.text:
Mech was designed and built before 6551 was proposed.
But we love that the Future Primitive folks independently arrived at a similar idea and decided to write and ERC standard around it, so we modified Mech to be compliant with the standard. This way all of our efforts are compatible and complementary.

text_entities.text:
Mech was designed and built before 6551 was proposed.
But we love that the Future Primitive folks independently arrived at a similar idea and decided to write and ERC standard around it, so we modified Mech to be compliant with the standard. This way all of our efforts are compatible and complementary.

messages.text: is it possible to interact with a contract from my token bound account? say mint an NFT or make a purchase on OS

text_entities.text: is it possible to interact with a contract from my token bound account? say mint an NFT or make a purchase on OS

messages.text:
Token bound accounts / mechs work exactly like any other contract account. They can own tokens, mint NFTs, participate in auctions, etc.

The only caveat is that many apps don't fully support contract accounts yet. But this is steadily improving.

text:
Hello 6551!

Airstack team is thrilled to launch

We have every 6551 deployed, historical and new within seconds of deployment. 

We will demo this to the working group on Thursday on the dev call. It is completely free right now for everyone to use. 

🤖 You can use our AI to help you learn the schemas and you can get graphql APIs for each query 🤖

Here are some example questions you can ask the AI at

:
1. Show the most recent 10 6551 accounts on ethereum and polygon
2. Show me all

ERC6551 accounts and their balances
3. Show all ERC65111 accounts owned by

and the token balances
4. Show sapienz_0.lens ERC6551 accounts
5. Show me 6551 accounts created on July 12, 2023 on Ethereum
6. Show the ERC6551 accounts on Polygon
7. Show the ERC6551 accounts on Ethereum

Please let us know any issues, bugs, or questions (either here or in Airstack dev chat). We are iterating rapidly.

Below i will also past a video example, a screenshot of the schema mapping, and save queries you can reference. On Thursday we'll also publish full developer docs and tutorials.

messages.text:
The launchpad will be for spinning up Moloch DAOs to sell 6551 NFT membership collections (that hold moloch shares/loot) and the funds will be instantly zapped into LPs, veTokens, LSDs etc. 

Funds remain locked (siloed) in the DeFi positions owned by the DAO.

The NFTs act as a portable governance and value accrual mechanism. Creating an NFT market of proportional representations of different yield bearing DeFi strategies.

There are several ways to configure yield allocation. Could flywheel it back into the positions, or split it into the treasury/NFTs themselves.

And we've been thinking on how we'd be able to show the value tied to these NFTs.

721 > 6551 > moloch shares/loot > treasury ( zodiac module on Safe) > LPs value etc. > value based on proportion of shares/loot

- ERC 20 is used for governance process
- Owner can delegate voting to their NPC
- All rev directed to the treasury

messages.text:
Hello everyone. Really excited by this tech. Semi-noob but trying to get my feet wet. 

If I were to create a TBA for an ERC 721 and send an ENS name (ERC 1155) to this account. The owner of the ERC 721 NFT would have control over the TBA & would have be able to transfer the ENS, but, to my understanding&testing, would not be able to implement ENS functionality such as “Set ENS as primary wallet name”? Has anyone encountered this / been able to find a work around? Thank you.

text_entities.text:
Hello everyone. Really excited by this tech. Semi-noob but trying to get my feet wet. 

If I were to create a TBA for an ERC 721 and send an ENS name (ERC 1155) to this account. The owner of the ERC 721 NFT would have control over the TBA & would have be able to transfer the ENS, but, to my understanding&testing, would not be able to implement ENS functionality such as “Set ENS as primary wallet name”? Has anyone encountered this / been able to find a work around? Thank you.

messages.text:
I realise a solution could be to create the TBA for the ENS name itself and then send the ERC 71 NFT to TBA controlled by the ENS. Which would still allow for all ENS functionality (to my knowledge). 

However if possible, I would prefer the first option as this would allow me to add royalties to the ERC 721 NFTs via OpenSea’s marketplace. Which is something I would like to do. Appreciate any feedback. Apologies if incorrect terminology — still learning.

text:
Hey guys, super excited to be here! I've been developing an identity-based project which was made for TBAs! As soon as I saw this new token standard, it was essentially what I was trying to do in the project. 

Sadly I don't have the technical experience to build this out. I'm BD and partnerships and used to consult on projects for people like Steve Aoki, Lamelo Ball, Mike Tyson, Val Kilmer, Sylvestor Stallone, NBA, etc.

One thing I learnt while working with those teams, is that having the right people for the job is more important than almost anything else!

Thanks to
for linking me to this chat group! Hope to connect with some of you guys further!

text_entities.text:
Hey guys, super excited to be here! I've been developing an identity-based project which was made for TBAs! As soon as I saw this new token standard, it was essentially what I was trying to do in the project. 

Sadly I don't have the technical experience to build this out. I'm BD and partnerships and used to consult on projects for people like Steve Aoki, Lamelo Ball, Mike Tyson, Val Kilmer, Sylvestor Stallone, NBA, etc.

One thing I learnt while working with those teams, is that having the right people for the job is more important than almost anything else!

text:
We are working on making it very easy to navigate the different levels of TBA, but you can already do that by creating some simple logic: check the balance of TBA accounts and return all NFT and they ERC6551 account addresses if any. Then take that account address and pass it via the same TokenBalance API and return what it has inside. Each output has a unique identifier which could be used to mark the 'depth' of the tree.

I've created a sample query showing the contents of an ERC6551 account and wheter the NFTs inside have their own ERC6551:

messages.text: Has anyone written/thought about gas considerations with deeply nested TBAs (i.e. a me -> NFT1 -> TBA1 -> NFT2 -> TBA2 -> ...). With enough nesting you'd be unable to do anything, due to the block gas limit. But what is that max? 3 layers? 300?

text_entities.text: Has anyone written/thought about gas considerations with deeply nested TBAs (i.e. a me -> NFT1 -> TBA1 -> NFT2 -> TBA2 -> ...). With enough nesting you'd be unable to do anything, due to the block gas limit. But what is that max? 3 layers? 300?

text: There is a stack limit of 1024

text_entities.text: There is a stack limit of 1024
@coinoplogan

messages.text: Ah right. I hadn't thought about that constraint. But that's separate from the gas concern

text_entities.text: Ah right. I hadn't thought about that constraint. But that's separate from the gas concern
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/70315824/solidity-stack-limit-reached-10241023-when-trying-to-burn#:~:text=The%20EVM%20stack%20has%201024,if%20you%20go%20too%20deep

messages.text: Just purely for gas, there is no max layer, it entirely depends on much each call costs in gas

text_entities.text: Just purely for gas, there is no max layer, it entirely depends on much each call costs in gas

messages.text: NFT1 -> TBA1 could cost 10m gas or 100k gas

text_entities.text: NFT1 -> TBA1 could cost 10m gas or 100k gas

messages.text: Sure, but given a particular implementation there would be a theoretical minimum gas per layer of delegation... The TBA has to verify ownership of the NFT at the very least. I'm sure it wouldn't be hard to calc this, I just was wondering if someone else had already done so. But now that I'm thinking about it perhaps that minimum is so low that in practice you'd have to worry more about the stack depth problem.

messages.text: each call only forwards 63/64 of remaining gas, so decay is exponential – with eth's block limit of 30m gas, assuming ~2300 gas is required for a cold external call (which is impractically low), that's at most ~610 calls before you'll fail with an out-of-gas on mainnet

text_entities.text: each call only forwards 63/64 of remaining gas, so decay is exponential – with eth's block limit of 30m gas, assuming ~2300 gas is required for a cold external call (which is impractically low), that's at most ~610 calls before you'll fail with an out-of-gas on mainnet

messages.text: This is true if you're doing chained calls (TBA 1 calls TBA 2 calls TBA 3 etc). There's some discussion in the EIP thread about enabling nested calls without chaining, which would make the gas limit considerations linear instead of exponential (N consecutive ownerOf calls). This would result in a much higher upper bound before out of gas issues

messages.text:
Hello fellow developers! my name is Eddy from Switzerland. I would like to express my gratitude to all those involved in the remarkable new ERC 6551. Currently, I'm working on a project that greatly benefits from this development. THANK YOU

But i'm having a little struggly to connect via the NFT.

I've successfully deployed the NFT Account contract, but i'm unable to connect to any platforms using WalletConnect, including OpenSea. I've used the "Connect with NFT" button and added the WalletConnect Link, which displays the message "Connected via Wallet Connect." However, I'm not experiencing any response or interaction on the platform. 

I'm wondering if there is a crucial step that I may have overlooked or if I'm making an error in the process. Any insights or guidance from experienced developers would be highly appreciated.

messages.text: Another question: once a erc721 have the erc6551 features is it possible to limit the amount of tokens that can hold? Or only allow certain kind of tokens to be stored into the NFT?

text_entities.text: Another question: once a erc721 have the erc6551 features is it possible to limit the amount of tokens that can hold? Or only allow certain kind of tokens to be stored into the NFT?

messages.text: By default no: ERC-6551 accounts are self sovereign just like any other wallet with no restrictions on what they can hold. You can implement an account contract that blocks certain assets from being received, but there is no way to fully prevent assets from being sent to the address due to ethereum's account model

text_entities.text: By default no: ERC-6551 accounts are self sovereign just like any other wallet with no restrictions on what they can hold. You can implement an account contract that blocks certain assets from being received, but there is no way to fully prevent assets from being sent to the address due to ethereum's account model

messages.text: Generally it's better to implement restrictions like this in the business logic of your contracts instead of the account logic

text_entities.text: Generally it's better to implement restrictions like this in the business logic of your contracts instead of the account logic

messages.text:
Gm folks! 
Last month I built a hackathon project at ETHWaterloo using ERC-6551 + Scaffold-ETH (and won a prize from Tokenbound 😎), and now I'm trying to continue working on it so I can properly brag about it in the BuidlGuidl. At the hackathon we deployed to Sepolia and used the already deployed Tokenbound contracts, but now I'd like to write some unit tests and running them on a live testnet doesn't seem ideal (correct me if I'm wrong). Obviously using a local testnet would require deploying the necessary ERC-6551 contracts, but as far as I can tell the SDK doesn't have methods for deploying them. 
So my question is, are there any Hardhat projects out there with deployment scripts for setting up these contracts? Or does anyone have any recommendations re: doing it myself?

text: Hi all, been lurking a bit and now actively working with a project following the standard. One question I have is about the depoyed Account implementation mentioned in the project docs:
The contract at the

address is verified as an AccountProxy, not an Account. 

Which presumably means that its upgrades are limited by an immutable AccountGuardian at
which is owned by EOA

? Who has this private key? Are there plans to transfer ownership to a multisig?

Given the above, it would make more sense for projects wishing to not limit future upgrades to a single EOA to deploy their own Account, AccountProxy, and AccountGuardian contracts, rather than depend on the deploy addresses provided in the docs.

I’d be curious to hear from others who have reviewed the ownership structure. Please let me know if I am missing something?

text_entities.text: Hi all, been lurking a bit and now actively working with a project following the standard. One question I have is about the depoyed Account implementation mentioned in the project docs:
https://docs.tokenbound.org/contracts/deployments
The contract at the

address is verified as an AccountProxy, not an Account. 

Which presumably means that its upgrades are limited by an immutable AccountGuardian at
which is owned by EOA

? Who has this private key? Are there plans to transfer ownership to a multisig?

Given the above, it would make more sense for projects wishing to not limit future upgrades to a single EOA to deploy their own Account, AccountProxy, and AccountGuardian contracts, rather than depend on the deploy addresses provided in the docs.

I’d be curious to hear from others who have reviewed the ownership structure. Please let me know if I am missing something?

text:
Awesome - which project are you working on?

The future primitive team holds this private key, and we plan to transfer ownership of the AccountGuardian to a multisig. This private key doesn't have permission to upgrade any token bound accounts, only to whitelist account implementations that can be upgraded to by token owners. This is to prevent malicious upgrade attacks (upgrading to an implementation that contains a backdoor before selling the NFT) or storage layout collisions.

If you don't want to opt into these protections / future upgrades to the tokenbound account implementation, you can use the implementation contract directly (
) without the proxy or deploy your own implementation

This is to prevent malicious upgrade attacks (upgrading to an implementation that contains a backdoor before selling the NFT) or storage layout collisions.

If you don't want to opt into these protections / future upgrades to the tokenbound account implementation, you can use the implementation contract directly (
) without the proxy or deploy your own implementation

Thanks. 

Yes, given that the implementation contract you referenced actually has the guardian as an immutable, it seems like we’d have to use a different implementation altogether if we wished to use a different guardian.

It looks like the guardian also determines trusted cross-chain executors?

in what scenario would this occur, where the chainId of the contract bytecode is not the chainId of the current execution? and in what circumstances would a trusted executor be set? If you already have a writeup on this, feel free to just point me to it.

messages.text: Trusted executors are a mechanism to allow holders to use their accounts cross-chain via a bridge. In this case, the trusted executor would be a contract that receives a message via a cross chain bridge and forwards it on to the account for excution. Notably, trusted executors only have access to token bound accounts for NFTs that are not native to the current chain

text_entities.text: Trusted executors are a mechanism to allow holders to use their accounts cross-chain via a bridge. In this case, the trusted executor would be a contract that receives a message via a cross chain bridge and forwards it on to the account for excution. Notably, trusted executors only have access to token bound accounts for NFTs that are not native to the current chain

messages.text: Re: the guardian, you would just need to deploy your own guardian and pass that as a constructor variable. Although I wouldn't recommend relying on the guardian pattern too much - we intend to reduce our reliance on it or remove it altogether in future versions so that there are no centralized components

messages.text: Right now we just add it to a mapping on a smart contract, but the signature based approach is interesting. A big reason for using a mapping is that permission can be easily revoked (in the case of a bridge hack for example), which might be more difficult to do with signatures

messages.text: I often come across topics that are above my level of understanding, but what I want to learn about. ERC-6551 is one of those topics. One way I’m solving that is creating a platform that connects learners like me to experts via platform integrations. Right now, there’s an integration for sending questions from platform —> Discord… and Discord server —> Discord server. I’m considering an integration from platform —> Telegram. I’m curious how open or opposed you all would be if questions came in to this group from learners on another platform curious about ERC-6551.

text_entities.text: I often come across topics that are above my level of understanding, but what I want to learn about. ERC-6551 is one of those topics. One way I’m solving that is creating a platform that connects learners like me to experts via platform integrations. Right now, there’s an integration for sending questions from platform —> Discord… and Discord server —> Discord server. I’m considering an integration from platform —> Telegram. I’m curious how open or opposed you all would be if questions came in to this group from learners on another platform curious about ERC-6551.

messages.text: ERC-6551 can be compatible with ERC-4337 at a smart contract level. The implementation contracts we've built are 4337 compatible. The Registry is designed to be compatible with the 4337 factory pattern

text_entities.text: ERC-6551 can be compatible with ERC-4337 at a smart contract level. The implementation contracts we've built are 4337 compatible. The Registry is designed to be compatible with the 4337 factory pattern

messages.text: Our implementation does support userOps (see the test cases for an example). Updating the entrypoint nonce is just a way to avoid having two nonces that have to be managed (one internal and one external)

messages.text: Yep, 6551 accounts bend the 4337 access rules slightly, and so won't necessarily work with all bundlers. You can use a bundler running in "unsafe" mode (which ignores storage access rules) to execute operations with 6551 accounts for now

text_entities.text: Yep, 6551 accounts bend the 4337 access rules slightly, and so won't necessarily work with all bundlers. You can use a bundler running in "unsafe" mode (which ignores storage access rules) to execute operations with 6551 accounts for now

messages.text: There's no need to bake the protocol into your NFT contract. As soon as your NFT is minted it will have an assigned token bound account address with no extra work needed on the NFT contract side

Hi guys,

I'm happy to announce that ERC-6551 TBA Wallet is integrated in Lenspeer.

Lenspeer, a social media app built on Lens Protocol. Along with the social features of the app, we have introduced Lens Wallet ( TBA Wallet ), any user can create an ERC-6551 Wallet for their Lens Profile NFT.

We are further exploring for more use cases and possibilities with ERC-6551

Website:
Twitter:

messages.text: Right now, if a TBA is deployed onchain, you can determine if it's a canonical TBA by introspecting the bytecode, computing the expected address, and comparing it to the actual address.

text_entities.text: Right now, if a TBA is deployed onchain, you can determine if it's a canonical TBA by introspecting the bytecode, computing the expected address, and comparing it to the actual address.

messages.text:
i’m thinking something simpler, just a bool “yes the registry deployed this contract” as a way for other smart contracts to use that as actionable info

ofc it’s not perfect since the TBAs are counterfactual, but eg an L2 bridge/messaging system could check if a recipient is a TBA on the L1 and reject it if there’s no easy way to access on the L2 (but maybe this isn’t an issue? admittedly hazy an the chainid stuff going on here)

if the registry itself references the mapping it can also prevent metamorphic deploys, though not sure how much of an issue that would be in practice

messages.text: We're hoping to make sure this isn't an issue by making it easy for token bound accounts to be accessible across chains (via native bridges). In this case, an NFT on an L1 could use it's address on an L2 by executing a transaction from 0x123 on L1 to 0x123 on L2. The address for each token bound account stays the same across all chains because of the chainId parameter

messages.text: Since chainId is a parameter to createAccount, each token bound account contract can be created at the same address across all chains. If the implementation you use supports cross-chain calls, you will be able to use your token bound account on many chains, despite the NFT only existing on one chain

messages.text: Because the registry contract is deployed at the same address on all chains, the contract at a given account address can also be deployed across all chains. If that contract supports execution via a cross-chain bridge, then you can send a transaction from your account on one chain to your account on another chain in order to control it. Functionally this allows you to use your token bound account with apps on any chain the implementation you're using supports

text_entities.text: Because the registry contract is deployed at the same address on all chains, the contract at a given account address can also be deployed across all chains. If that contract supports execution via a cross-chain bridge, then you can send a transaction from your account on one chain to your account on another chain in order to control it. Functionally this allows you to use your token bound account with apps on any chain the implementation you're using supports

messages.text: (Assuming you’re also referencing 6220 as well). There’s a fundamental difference. Those specs are specifically for nft composability and around a specific usage of nft chained ownership. 6551 is about providing nft’s with a wallet and identity. The fact that this wallet/identity can own other nft’s is just one aspect of what it enables and the only real overlap with the rmrk proposals.

text_entities.text: (Assuming you’re also referencing 6220 as well). There’s a fundamental difference. Those specs are specifically for nft composability and around a specific usage of nft chained ownership. 6551 is about providing nft’s with a wallet and identity. The fact that this wallet/identity can own other nft’s is just one aspect of what it enables and the only real overlap with the rmrk proposals.

messages.text: Personally, I find and back the 6551 spec because it uses native ethereum constructs (wallet addresses) to handle the ownership chain and doesn’t need any new specs to interpret the ownership chain.

text_entities.text: Personally, I find and back the 6551 spec because it uses native ethereum constructs (wallet addresses) to handle the ownership chain and doesn’t need any new specs to interpret the ownership chain.

messages.text: Hi everyone, excited to be here. Quick background on myself. I’ve been a developer in crypto since 2017, and am now a founder in web3. I helped bytes32 found the web3SecurityDAO and then managed the merge with the OpenSense community. I’m a strong believer in the ethos of our space and am highly interested in progressing new standards and contributing to these types of discussions. Lately in some work I’ve been doing on 4337, I started studying 6551. It quickly became apparent that the design space here is massive and I’m excited to chat with everyone here about it! 🤝

Is there any resource you can point me to where I can see an example implementation?
I don’t understand how the TBA can be attached to an ERC1155. If you own 1 token and I own 1, and we both have TBAs via those tokens, how can it differentiate between the two tokens?

text_entities.text:
Is there any resource you can point me to where I can see an example implementation?
I don’t understand how the TBA can be attached to an ERC1155. If you own 1 token and I own 1, and we both have TBAs via those tokens, how can it differentiate between the two tokens?

messages.text: There would be a single TBA that both tokens share in this case, since there is a single tokenId

text_entities.text: There would be a single TBA that both tokens share in this case, since there is a single tokenId

messages.text: That makes sense. Then by custom auth do you mean that transactions can be made to require signatures from arbitrary number of erc1155 token holders?

text_entities.text: That makes sense. Then by custom auth do you mean that transactions can be made to require signatures from arbitrary number of erc1155 token holders?

messages.text: I.e transaction requires 60% of holders to sign

text_entities.text: I.e transaction requires 60% of holders to sign

messages.text: Yep, that's one example. Another would be requiring that a given sender owns >60% of tokens to execute. Up to the implementation to decide

messages.text:
Gm, quick intro: I'm Santo, I work in fashion / web3. I launched a 3D avatar collection (Pioneers5555) and have been looking to make it dynamic to incentivize holders to collect sneakers from our designers/brands ecosystem. 

Initially we wanted to allow our holders to mint a dynamic soulbound token on Polygon but TBA on 6551 make much more sense for us. I met Benny a few months ago after purchasing a Sapienz. 

I'm looking to learn, share ideas and perhaps work with people interested to test a few things with us!

messages.text: Hey guys! My team and I are building an identity system leveraging Bitcoin proof of work. Our startup is in the early phases, and we're part of the Bitcoin Startup Lab pre-accelerator. Our blockchain domains will be on an EVM-compatible chain, so erc6551 would be supported. Instead of creating a regular NFT, we plan to implement something similar to what's done with ENS in the picture above. We believe decentralized identity backed by Bitcoin is a good starting point for a future of interoperable multi-chain DIDs. Who wants to help me bring attention to erc6551 on Bitcoin? 😀

text_entities.text: Hey guys! My team and I are building an identity system leveraging Bitcoin proof of work. Our startup is in the early phases, and we're part of the Bitcoin Startup Lab pre-accelerator. Our blockchain domains will be on an EVM-compatible chain, so erc6551 would be supported. Instead of creating a regular NFT, we plan to implement something similar to what's done with ENS in the picture above. We believe decentralized identity backed by Bitcoin is a good starting point for a future of interoperable multi-chain DIDs. Who wants to help me bring attention to erc6551 on Bitcoin? 😀

messages.text: What is the good aspect of it? I'd imagine that while it does keep things consistent because it treats the TBA the same as any other wallet, it still defeats the purpose of a SBT.

text_entities.text: What is the good aspect of it? I'd imagine that while it does keep things consistent because it treats the TBA the same as any other wallet, it still defeats the purpose of a SBT.

messages.text:
my current assumption for this is that I currently understand SBT's as being tied to people, and so if you can transfer SBT's between people through TBA it breaks that link.

i might be thinking of this in the wrong perspective

text_entities.text:
my current assumption for this is that I currently understand SBT's as being tied to people, and so if you can transfer SBT's between people through TBA it breaks that link.

i might be thinking of this in the wrong perspective

messages.text: There's nothing wrong with it IMO. It just opens new use cases. For example you can have a soulbound reputation soulbound to the user (think achievements for onchain actions). Or you can have a soulbound to NFT through it's TBA (think unbreakable curse on the character NFT). It's up to you to choose what to soulbound it to. As it's soulbound to it's immediate parent in this sense (well with TBA there's an account in between, so it's not truly soulbound to NFT, but there are standards where nested NFTs have no account in the middle, but still the logic is the same)

text_entities.text: There's nothing wrong with it IMO. It just opens new use cases. For example you can have a soulbound reputation soulbound to the user (think achievements for onchain actions). Or you can have a soulbound to NFT through it's TBA (think unbreakable curse on the character NFT). It's up to you to choose what to soulbound it to. As it's soulbound to it's immediate parent in this sense (well with TBA there's an account in between, so it's not truly soulbound to NFT, but there are standards where nested NFTs have no account in the middle, but still the logic is the same)

messages.text:
This was my point too. However, the point made here was that in scenarios associated with gaming, the Sbt is bonded to the soul I.e the character NFT. 

Thus that sbt can be tradeable to different EoA’s, but will always be associated to the NFT’s soul. 


The bad for me was in a Defi context. It is likely that TBA as a standard will need a re-write or several app level changes to be usable in Defi. Cannot use things like Quadrata passport without being in contravention of the law if TBA’s become liquid

messages.text: With the previous design of the account interface 1155 accounts would have been non-standard to implement because of the required owner function. messages.text: Exactly this - the search space is infinite, so you can easily run out of gas when checking for cycles inside the receiver hook. You also cannot prevent against cycles using counterfactual accounts since the token details for them are not published onchain. It also means that receiving any token to a deployed account is much more expensive

text: hey Jayden. Does the creation of erc6551 conflict with the idea of soulbound token which is meant to not be tradable?

text_entities.text: @jaydenwindle
hey Jayden. Does the creation of erc6551 conflict with the idea of soulbound token which is meant to not be tradable?

messages.text: It's impossible to make a soulbound token not tradable, as even with an EOA you could transfer the keys to the account to someone else. Soulbound tokens are better understood as account-bound tokens. Soulbound tokens can be tied to a token bound account, in which case they could be transferred by transferring the NFT

text_entities.text: It's impossible to make a soulbound token not tradable, as even with an EOA you could transfer the keys to the account to someone else. Soulbound tokens are better understood as account-bound tokens. Soulbound tokens can be tied to a token bound account, in which case they could be transferred by transferring the NFT

gm, diggin back in after being away for a while, and excited by all the progress! I have a couple questions...

1. Remind me: is the intent to drive usage around a canonical registry per chain, or is the expectation that there will be multiple registries focused on different use cases / requirements (as long as they conform to

)?

2. If the answer to the above is the former, is there a reason why the current registry implementation doesn't use a clone factory for cheaper deployments?

text_entities.text:
gm, diggin back in after being away for a while, and excited by all the progress! I have a couple questions...

1. Remind me: is the intent to drive usage around a canonical registry per chain, or is the expectation that there will be multiple registries focused on different use cases / requirements (as long as they conform to
IERC6551Registry

)?

2. If the answer to the above is the former, is there a reason why the current registry implementation doesn't use a clone factory for cheaper deployments?

messages.text:

messages.text: Hello all. Would it be possible to have a TBA for an ERC721, but with an extra condition that would not allow a specific NFT sent to the TBA, to be removed from said TBA?

text_entities.text: Hello all. Would it be possible to have a TBA for an ERC721, but with an extra condition that would not allow a specific NFT sent to the TBA, to be removed from said TBA?

messages.text:
Don't think that's possible 🤔 to add such condition on the TBA contract since the NFT balance data are independent (assuming the TBA does not have write access to the NFT to remove the NFT balance to 0) and live outside the TBA contract code

Only if there's a condition in the NFT transfer function to blacklist the transfer to the given TBA, then that might be possible to avoid any transfer to the TBA

text: Hey guys 👋, for those who couldn't attend the demo yesterday, we want to give you a brief overview of what we're building at

We are developing an aggregation platform dedicated to showcasing projects related to ERC-6551. This includes both projects that are live on the mainnet and those still in development.

Our team has curated a list of projects. If you're a project owner, please don't hesitate to reach out if you need to claim your project or request an edit. For the projects that are not listed yet, we encourage you to use our 'List a project' function.

Lastly, we are always open to connecting with builders in the space. Please feel free to dm me if you’d like to chat!

messages.text:
Glad you liked it! It is multiple API calls chained!

The concept driving the visualizer involves implementing a Breadth-First Search (BFS) approach. Initially, an API call is made for the primary wallet, retrieving comprehensive metadata for every NFT associated with this wallet. Subsequently, we interact with the contract to determine the addresses corresponding to each NFT within that wallet. This procedure is then iterated for each newly obtained address, allowing for an expansive exploration of the network.

Subsequently, we interact with the contract to determine the addresses corresponding to each NFT within that wallet. This procedure is then iterated for each newly obtained address, allowing for an expansive exploration of the network.

Hello hello 👋🏼 TBA community! 🚀

Excited to share we're launching Beta V1 of the Dippi API!

With Dippi, you can

, bridging the gap between traditional user experiences and the decentralized world. 

Unlike Web3 Auth or Magic Link, Dippi stands out with its vision for a unique P2P Mix-net Network to

text.text: ensure users maintain 100% sovereignty and control over their private keys.

text:
Seamlessly aligned with Ethereum's evolving landscape.
-

Generate EOAs, Token Bound Accounts or Smart Contract Wallets .

A dedicated module is underway for smooth transitions from other MPC solutions.

text_entities.text:
Hello hello 👋🏼 TBA community! 🚀

Excited to share we're launching Beta V1 of the Dippi API!

With Dippi, you can
effortlessly generate wallets using emails

, bridging the gap between traditional user experiences and the decentralized world. 

Unlike Web3 Auth or Magic Link, Dippi stands out with its vision for a unique P2P Mix-net Network to
ensure users maintain 100% sovereignty and control over their private keys.
Features on the Horizon:
Account Abstraction Compatibility:

Seamlessly aligned with Ethereum's evolving landscape.
-
EOAs and Beyond:

Generate EOAs, Token Bound Accounts or Smart Contract Wallets .
-
Decentralized Migration Module:

A dedicated module is underway for smooth transitions from other MPC solutions.
-
Proof of Personhood Module:

Integrating diverse authentication methods (biometrics, keystroke and 2FA) for robust user verification.

For those who integrate our API in the next 72 hours, we're gifting a unique NFT (ERC-6551). This isn't just any NFT; it promises a range of future perks exclusive to its holders.

Jump in, test our APIs, and be part of the future we're building with Dippi!
- Link to our docs:
https://docs.dippi.xyz/
- Create you dev user here:
https://client.dippi.xyz/
Have any doubts, please feel free to send a DM at
@doris_hernz

Wagmi 🚀,

I've been recently examining the contract code and SDK examples related to ERC-6551. Could anyone explain how the SDK functions in this context? Thank you!

Hey Melbin,

Just curious so are you trying to fetch the ERC6551 that is owned by a given ERC721 or are you trying to fetch the owner?

text_entities.text:
Hey Melbin,

Just curious so are you trying to fetch the ERC6551 that is owned by a given ERC721 or are you trying to fetch the owner?

messages.text: THe ERC 6551 that is owned by a 721. From what I understand the 6551 is also a contract, but it has a wallet address associated with it right?

text_entities.text: THe ERC 6551 that is owned by a 721. From what I understand the 6551 is also a contract, but it has a wallet address associated with it right?

messages.text: When you add a 721 to the registry, you get a contract address and a wallet address. I am looking for a means to get that wallet address with a query

text_entities.text: When you add a 721 to the registry, you get a contract address and a wallet address. I am looking for a means to get that wallet address with a query

messages.text:
Correct, so essentially 6551 is a smart contract wallet that is owned by a 721 and it is bounded to that particular 721, cannot be transfered

The wallet address you're referring to might be the EOA wallet that own the 721 that own the 6551

text_entities.text:
