text: For implementations deployed with a custom salt, you can interact via the SDK by passing the resulting implementationAddress when instantiating the client. We have documentation here:
Out of the box, the SDK uses the default deployed addresses:

text_entities.text: For implementations deployed with a custom salt, you can interact via the SDK by passing the resulting implementationAddress when instantiating the client. We have documentation here:
https://docs.tokenbound.org/sdk/customAccounts
Out of the box, the SDK uses the default deployed addresses:
https://docs.tokenbound.org/contracts/deployments

text:
We've just released version 0.3.3 of the SDK, adding new methods to simplify some tasks that the community has been asking about:

- checkAccountDeployment() to verify whether a tokenbound account has been deployed at that address
- deconstructBytecode(), for segmenting bytecode into its constituent parts (think salt, implementationAddress, tokenId, tokenContract, chainId)
- getNFT(), a convenience method that grabs the NFT-specific details from the deconstructed bytecode so you can tell which NFT is associated with the deployed account
Full docs:

text_entities.text:
We've just released version 0.3.3 of the SDK, adding new methods to simplify some tasks that the community has been asking about:

- checkAccountDeployment() to verify whether a tokenbound account has been deployed at that address
- deconstructBytecode(), for segmenting bytecode into its constituent parts (think salt, implementationAddress, tokenId, tokenContract, chainId)
- getNFT(), a convenience method that grabs the NFT-specific details from the deconstructed bytecode so you can tell which NFT is associated with the deployed account
https://www.npmjs.com/package/@tokenbound/sdk
Full docs:
https://docs.tokenbound.org/sdk/methods

As promised, we just dropped a bunch of new 6551 tutorials: 

🌲Learn how to use Airstack to traverse the ERC6551 tree, either ⬆️ upwards or ⬇️ downwards.

In this guide you will learn how to use Airstack to:
1. Traverse Up ERC6551 Tree By ERC6551 Account Address
2. Traverse Up ERC6551 Tree By NFT
3. Traverse Down ERC6551 Tree By EOA Address
4. Traverse Down ERC6551 Tree By NFT

text_entities.text:
Working through deploying ERC-6551 step by step. I've deployed following contracted:

1. 6551 implementation:
https://polygonscan.com/address/0x84e1e8570b4fcd0ab3f8ef5d7f96905790a894e6#writeContract
2. Registry contract:
https://polygonscan.com/address/0x74e74de29f103ebdd4b163697acc63cb097cf30b#writeContract
3. ERC-721 contract:
https://polygonscan.com/address/0x3a2004df4c7319eac1bcf9305d94af8f1afa8b8b#writeContract
I then minted an NFT to my account:
https://polygonscan.com/token/0x3a2004df4c7319eac1bcf9305d94af8f1afa8b8b?a=0
and then called the
createAccount
method on the registry contract with the minted token details:
https://polygonscan.com/tx/0x19102bb9110116f3b87353adc96e1e0cfdb90ece62ea6e6c9e5f00300e0114ad#internal
which generated an account:
https://polygonscan.com/address/0x7e6cef91cf19d104f2cd699d92394d45074cc42e

My question: is there a way to see the relation between the newly generated account and the NFT? Wondering how to use the NFT to interact with its newly generated account such as sending / approving transactions. Assuming it's just because these methods haven't been implemented in UIs? Also not seeing the tokenbound fingerprint logo on the OpenSea page of the token:
https://opensea.io/assets/matic/0x3a2004df4c7319eac1bcf9305d94af8f1afa8b8b/0
Thanks!

to get additional information about the deployment at the account address (eg. implementationAddress, salt, etc.)
As for txs, these are available via the
function exposed on the 6551 account ABI. Using the SDK, we expose

Depending on the level at which you're working, these code examples might be helpful:

text.text: Usage of both prepareExecuteCall and executeCall in an example front-end app:

text: These examples are pretty trivial. We're working to expand on the documentation and SDK implementation to provide some of the more common use cases out of the box (eg. NFT, ETH, + ERC-20 transfers)

text_entities.text: @jackdishman
the latest SDK release (0.3.4, from today) provides additional methods to let you dig into this a bit more. Firstly, you can use the
getNFT()
method to get info about the origin NFT for a Tokenbound account. You can use
deconstructBytecode()
to get additional information about the deployment at the account address (eg. implementationAddress, salt, etc.)
SDK docs here:
https://docs.tokenbound.org/sdk/methods
As for txs, these are available via the
executeCall()
function exposed on the 6551 account ABI. Using the SDK, we expose
prepareExecuteCall()
executeCall()

, which should suit your needs.

Depending on the level at which you're working, these code examples might be helpful:
SDK implementation of
executeCall:
https://github.com/tokenbound/sdk/blob/bbb93981b9c5919466091597600af2819e6f2fd5/packages/sdk/src/TokenboundClient.ts#L255
Usage of both prepareExecuteCall and executeCall in an example front-end app:
https://github.com/tokenbound/sdk/blob/main/examples/vite-wagmi-viem/src/App.tsx
These examples are pretty trivial. We're working to expand on the documentation and SDK implementation to provide some of the more common use cases out of the box (eg. NFT, ETH, + ERC-20 transfers)

messages.text: Scenario is: 0. NFT has nested assets that have an approved operator that can move those assets. 1. Owner of NFT with nested assets lists NFT for sale. 2. Seller detects NFT buy tx in the mempool. 3. Approved operator frontruns the sale by rugging all assets from the NFT. 4. Buyer gets the NFT with no assets.

text:
Quick reminder:

Thank you everyone for joining this working group! A few important rules:

1. Everyone here is a builder and actively providing opinions or contributing to the open source standard

2. We'll try to keep memes to a minimum and will enforce if it gets too out of hands. The purpose of this group is to build together and to share work or ask questions about ERC 6551

3. We have weekly dev/design calls on Thursdays

4. At any time, we encourage people to share their MVPs or projects using ERC 6551/TBAs. However no promotions for airdrops or projects that you are launching. We want to keep this group focused on building and on dev related questions.

5. We're here to rally the community towards making NFTs an awesome thing to own and collect. We mostly come from a development perspective rather than a shilling one, so please be mindful of that

6. The biggest contribuition you can make to this open standard is to share your feedback here:
7. If you have any issues with the SDK

or with anything feel free to share your questions in this group

8. Be nice. Be friendly. Be helpful to each other. No harrassment is tolerated and will be removed immediately. 

9. All constructive ideas are welcomed and we encourage healthy debates. We are aware that the NFT ecosystem is huge and there are so many projects that have different use cases. ERC 6551 is designed to be flexible, composable, and open so that anyone can customize it as they see fit.

10. When referencing ERC 6551 we usually call them Token Bound Accounts (TBAs). That is the most technically correct term.

text_entities.text:
Quick reminder:

Thank you everyone for joining this working group! A few important rules:

1. Everyone here is a builder and actively providing opinions or contributing to the open source standard

2. We'll try to keep memes to a minimum and will enforce if it gets too out of hands. The purpose of this group is to build together and to share work or ask questions about ERC 6551

3. We have weekly dev/design calls on Thursdays
https://calendar.google.com/calendar/u/1/r?cid=Y185OTNjZmNjOGRjNWE5MDdlM2Y1N2M4YWI0NTQwYzRiMTVhNTQ4ODc2YmQ0OWMyMWEwYmExY2RkMGU2MDE4ZjVhQGdyb3VwLmNhbGVuZGFyLmdvb2dsZS5jb20

4. At any time, we encourage people to share their MVPs or projects using ERC 6551/TBAs. However no promotions for airdrops or projects that you are launching. We want to keep this group focused on building and on dev related questions.

5. We're here to rally the community towards making NFTs an awesome thing to own and collect. We mostly come from a development perspective rather than a shilling one, so please be mindful of that

6. The biggest contribuition you can make to this open standard is to share your feedback here:
https://ethereum-magicians.org/t/erc-6551-non-fungible-token-bound-accounts/13030
7. If you have any issues with the SDK
https://docs.tokenbound.org/

or with anything feel free to share your questions in this group

8. Be nice. Be friendly. Be helpful to each other. No harrassment is tolerated and will be removed immediately. 

9. All constructive ideas are welcomed and we encourage healthy debates. We are aware that the NFT ecosystem is huge and there are so many projects that have different use cases. ERC 6551 is designed to be flexible, composable, and open so that anyone can customize it as they see fit.

10. When referencing ERC 6551 we usually call them Token Bound Accounts (TBAs). That is the most technically correct term.

text: This is a good overview of the attack vector. Ultimately, marketplaces are responsible for preventing this, not the account. The account is responsible for exposing information to the marketplace which it can use to protect against these types of attacks.

is one mechanism to do so.

The current implementation uses the nonce to represent state, which is able to prevent against call-based front running but not approval-based front running. However, now that
in the new interface, accounts can implement more robust expressions of state that marketplaces can interpret.

text_entities.text: This is a good overview of the attack vector. Ultimately, marketplaces are responsible for preventing this, not the account. The account is responsible for exposing information to the marketplace which it can use to protect against these types of attacks.
state

is one mechanism to do so.

The current implementation uses the nonce to represent state, which is able to prevent against call-based front running but not approval-based front running. However, now that
state != nonce
in the new interface, accounts can implement more robust expressions of state that marketplaces can interpret.

messages.text: I think it would be useful for the reference opinionated implementation to provide this exposure of state (maybe merkle root of an asset tree)

text_entities.text: I think it would be useful for the reference opinionated implementation to provide this exposure of state (maybe merkle root of an asset tree)

messages.text:
Definitely agree - planning to change how the tokenbound implementation handles this in the next version of the contracts. Merkle roots are tough because they have to get updated every time an asset (or sub-asset if using trees) gets transferred. This is both expensive and fraught with edge cases. 

Currently leaning towards making state a hash of calldata + previous state. This would allow users to specify valid future states when submitting a marketplace order, for example marking an order conditional on the current holder executing a transaction that revokes all approvals

Hey all, currently learning more about TBAs, and heard they reduce gas usage. Let’s say I want to create 10 TBA wallets, each with 10 USDC and 10 DAI.

Is there a way to only have ~10 transactions to accomplish this by filling each wallet with the 10 USDC and DAI at the same time, or would it be closer to 20 transactions (one for transferring 10 USDC, another one for transferring 10 DAI to the TBA)?

messages.text: Hey all, David from Polygon, we are super excited about TBA’s and have been working with our community of devs on some open source utilities for the community. Will share repos next week (pending internal audit) but we have initial reference implantation of crosschain TBAs (example: your Lens Account on POS can control a TBA on ETH, Bored Ape on mainnet can control TBA on zkEVM). We are starting with the Polygon chains, but a chain agnostic reference (PoS <> OP, Scroll <> FTM) is in the works targeting late Sept release.

messages.text: 6551 is primarily focused on ERC-721 tokens, so the behavior of createAccount is not likely to change. However, you can (ab)use the salt parameter of the createAccount function to pass additional data to account implementations that support 1155 tokens (since the salt parameter changes the address of the account and can be read by the implementation)

text_entities.text: 6551 is primarily focused on ERC-721 tokens, so the behavior of createAccount is not likely to change. However, you can (ab)use the salt parameter of the createAccount function to pass additional data to account implementations that support 1155 tokens (since the salt parameter changes the address of the account and can be read by the implementation)

Hi! New to 6551 and currently building apps for AW. Can someone save me time and answer a few quick questions?
1. Is the 6551 wallet design pretty much the same as 4337 like the design image bellow with userops, validators, paymaster etc 
2. Once I create a 6551 wallet with tokenbound, are there any wallet interfaces/apps for me to start transacting?
3. How will the wallet app prove ownership of the 6551?
Thank you!

text_entities.text:
Hi! New to 6551 and currently building apps for AW. Can someone save me time and answer a few quick questions?
1. Is the 6551 wallet design pretty much the same as 4337 like the design image bellow with userops, validators, paymaster etc 
2. Once I create a 6551 wallet with tokenbound, are there any wallet interfaces/apps for me to start transacting?
3. How will the wallet app prove ownership of the 6551?
Thank you!

text: Hey

I can help you answer 2 & 3:

2. You can use
or

's wallet, for now you 

For now most interface is limited to transferring assets afaik, but if you wanna make custom raw tx, then the tokenbound team have SDK w/ method
for you to call any smart contracts:

3. For proving ownership of 6551 owned by an EOA, you'll need to be able to traverse the 6551 tree upward to check which EOA is owning the given 6551 address, to do that you can use Airstack. Here's a demo query for you to test out:
Also documentation for Airstack on this:
Feel free to let me know if you have any questions especially regarding to Airstack, happy to help anytime 🙏

text_entities.text: Hey
@Juke9222

I can help you answer 2 & 3:

2. You can use
https://tokenbound.org
or
https://lenspeer.com

's wallet, for now you 

For now most interface is limited to transferring assets afaik, but if you wanna make custom raw tx, then the tokenbound team have SDK w/ method
executeCall
for you to call any smart contracts:
https://docs.tokenbound.org/sdk/methods#executecall

3. For proving ownership of 6551 owned by an EOA, you'll need to be able to traverse the 6551 tree upward to check which EOA is owning the given 6551 address, to do that you can use Airstack. Here's a demo query for you to test out:
https://app.airstack.xyz/query/epmTCtAefH
Also documentation for Airstack on this:
https://docs.airstack.xyz/airstack-docs-and-faqs/guides/token-bound-accounts/traverse-erc6551-tree#traverse-up-erc6551-tree-by-erc6551-account-address
Feel free to let me know if you have any questions especially regarding to Airstack, happy to help anytime 🙏

messages.text: This is correct - the address space for an NFT is theoretically very large. However, I don't think this will cause users to "crash". EOA wallets using a seed phrase also have an infinite address space, but in practice users are fine using only a small subset of that. I expect the same to happen with TBAs

text_entities.text: This is correct - the address space for an NFT is theoretically very large. However, I don't think this will cause users to "crash". EOA wallets using a seed phrase also have an infinite address space, but in practice users are fine using only a small subset of that. I expect the same to happen with TBAs

messages.text: 6551 doesn't depend on 4337 explicitly, so the design for 6551 accounts is actually much simpler than this. However, 6551 accounts work well with the 4337 execution path so they can be used together if the 6551 implementation you're using supports it

text_entities.text: 6551 doesn't depend on 4337 explicitly, so the design for 6551 accounts is actually much simpler than this. However, 6551 accounts work well with the 4337 execution path so they can be used together if the 6551 implementation you're using supports it

messages.text: Every TBA is deployed as an ERC-1167 minimal proxy. This means that all calls are delegated to an implementation contract which implements the 6551 account interface

text_entities.text: Every TBA is deployed as an ERC-1167 minimal proxy. This means that all calls are delegated to an implementation contract which implements the 6551 account interface

text: Hi! Is anyone working on building an ERC20-bound account to perform functionalities akin to an on-chain DAO wallet? Here's what I'm envisioning for the execution interface:
The
parameter would initiate a transfer of the corresponding ERC20 token to the TBA to vote on
execution. If the tokens for a specific
exceed a predetermined threshold (e.g., half of the supply), the
function could be invoked by anyone, provided that the
matches the
. The

interface would allow voters to retrieve their tokens in the manner hardcoded into the contract.

I believe this concept might be beneficial for projects looking to support DAOs more conveniently. However, implementing the corresponding logic can be prone to issues. I'm curious if anyone has already tackled similar tasks, so that we don't reinvent the wheel.

messages.text:
Hello Team,

First and foremost, I'd like to express my gratitude for all the efforts you've put into the project. It's truly refreshing to witness innovation in the web3 domain, beyond just JPEGs.

We are exploring the possibility of creating a native ERC6551 token. The concept revolves around having a standard ERC721 contract, and upon every event, registering the tokenId as ERC6551. Is this feasible? Do you see any technical or logical concerns? Additionally, could you provide an estimate on the extra gas consumption this might entail?

Thank you for your insights!

Thank you for your insights!

messages.text:
Understood.

From what I gather (and do correct me if I've misunderstood), the token-bound address is consistently computed based on variables such as the contract address and tokenId. However, for a user to access this wallet, they would need to deploy a contract through your dApp (or using the provided SDK), correct?

We're contemplating ways to further streamline this for users. One idea is to integrate the wallet contract creation directly into the minting process. What are your thoughts on this?

messages.text:
Hi, I have a question regarding nesting NFTs. 
There is a use case that I want to achieve but I don't know if erc-6551 will be able to accomplish that or not. 

Use case - Let's say I am the owner of a nestable NFT and people can invest money/send tokens to my NFT address, For every investment in my NFT, I will mint and new child NFT from my NFT and send it to the investor address. Now after let's say 1 year whoever has that child NFT will get some rewards for investing and get their investment back and the child NFT will be burned. Now all of this will be handled by the owner of root nft, like burning of child nfts or transferring the rewards to the owner of each child nfts.

From what I have researched, each NFT will be owned by the parent nft, but is it possible to give ownership to an address, but The owner of nft at the top should still have some power over that nft like burning the nft or taking ownership of the nft.

text_entities.text:
Hi, I have a question regarding nesting NFTs. 
There is a use case that I want to achieve but I don't know if erc-6551 will be able to accomplish that or not. 

Use case - Let's say I am the owner of a nestable NFT and people can invest money/send tokens to my NFT address, For every investment in my NFT, I will mint and new child NFT from my NFT and send it to the investor address. Now after let's say 1 year whoever has that child NFT will get some rewards for investing and get their investment back and the child NFT will be burned. Now all of this will be handled by the owner of root nft, like burning of child nfts or transferring the rewards to the owner of each child nfts.

From what I have researched, each NFT will be owned by the parent nft, but is it possible to give ownership to an address, but The owner of nft at the top should still have some power over that nft like burning the nft or taking ownership of the nft.

messages.text:
Welcome Lupin! This is an interesting use case with many different angles you could approach it from. You could certainly create some custom smart contract logic on your end that handles minting NFTs into the Tokenbound account of an NFT, along with a frontend that lets users deposit assets to an account — use tokens to represent actions a user takes, set rules about how users can interact with the NFTs etc.
Initially, only the wallet that owns a Tokenbound account has control of every asset “nested” inside, all the way down the line. I would start thinking about which user actions for your use case are possible and helpful to handle with all the normal operations that come with owning a token in an account — transferring, setting approvals, etc. — and then I would consider everything else external contract work or a custom implementation.

Initially, only the wallet that owns a Tokenbound account has control of every asset “nested” inside, all the way down the line. I would start thinking about which user actions for your use case are possible and helpful to handle with all the normal operations that come with owning a token in an account — transferring, setting approvals, etc. — and then I would consider everything else external contract work or a custom implementation.

messages.text: Interesting use case! For this I would likely recommend spinning up a new NFT contract that handles the investment / child NFT minting logic, and make the TBA for the root NFT the owner of that NFT contract. That way any lockup / reward logic can live at the NFT contract level, while admin rights on that contract will be owned by the root NFT

Hey guys question,

I got this part in my mint function that creates a new TBA, mints 5 trait NFTs and then should transfer those NFTs to the TBA:

        ``address newAccount = _erc6551Registry.createAccount(0xD2F5793e91D3043002f478aa06A023D4FAE12777, 5, address(this), newTokenId, 0, "");

        for(uint i = 0; i < 5; i++) {
            uint256 traitId = _traitNFTContract.mint(address(this), "someMetadata"); // Mint directly to this contract
            _traitNFTContract.safeTransferFrom(address(this), newAccount, traitId); // Transfer from the contract to the new account
        }``

However i'm getting an error
ERC721: transfer to non ERC721Receiver implementer".
Debug the transaction to get more information.

Does this have something to do with how i create the account as it suggests the newAccount can't receive ERC721?

messages.text: BTW, the upgradeable account might be a dangerous design for ERC6551 that the previous token owner could upgrade the TBA to a malicious implementation before he transfer the NFT to next owner. If the next owner doesn't check the TBA implementation and transfer funds into the TBA, his/her assets can be stolen away by the previous owner. Maybe UI/application layer design is required to prevent this to happen

text:
Hello, I am a contract development engineer, and I have identified some issues with the deployed Account contract under the ERC6551 protocol while developing my own project.

1. In the Account.sol contract, the setPermission method is supported, and if permissions[owner][caller] = true, it can call the executeCall method.
2. The above functionality becomes ineffective when the owner changes, as permissions[new_owner][caller] = false.
3. However, if there is a scenario like EOA->NFT1->CA1->NFT2->CA2->NFT3->CA3, if each time a new entity is added, setPermission is called to set it as EOA, then when EOA transfer NFT1 to another EOA2, NFT2's owner is still CA1. Therefore, the permissions relationship doesn't become ineffective, meaning that EOA can still interact with the CA2 contract and transfer NFT3 to itself."

I would like to know how you are approaching this issue and whether there are any corresponding solutions in place or planned for future upgrades？

text_entities.text: @jaydenwindle

Hello, I am a contract development engineer, and I have identified some issues with the deployed Account contract under the ERC6551 protocol while developing my own project.

1. In the Account.sol contract, the setPermission method is supported, and if permissions[owner][caller] = true, it can call the executeCall method.
2. The above functionality becomes ineffective when the owner changes, as permissions[new_owner][caller] = false.
3. However, if there is a scenario like EOA->NFT1->CA1->NFT2->CA2->NFT3->CA3, if each time a new entity is added, setPermission is called to set it as EOA, then when EOA transfer NFT1 to another EOA2, NFT2's owner is still CA1. Therefore, the permissions relationship doesn't become ineffective, meaning that EOA can still interact with the CA2 contract and transfer NFT3 to itself."

I would like to know how you are approaching this issue and whether there are any corresponding solutions in place or planned for future upgrades？

messages.text:
Hey so this actually happens on a centralized system! 

Basically we have a server that checks if the NFT owns the gear. If you’re going to equip we add the item to a mapping table and use our rendering engine to layer the images in order. 

There’s a webhook listening to when gear that has been transferred and remove the mapping from the sapienz and that gear and re-render the layers of the sapienz!

text: This is an interesting edge case, thanks for documenting it! This is expected behavior on the accounts (as permissions are keyed by owner), but you're right that it can enable fraudulent behavior by malicious owners. A similar fraud vector exists with token approvals using TBAs. The primary tool for protecting against fraud is the

function on the account. Marketplaces and other applications should check the value of state matches the value that a user expects prior to transferring the NFT, which would ensure that no malicious permissions were added prior to execution of the order. In the future, this could also be mitigated by limiting an account's ability to set permissions when nested (although this does limit the usefulness of permissions within TBAs). Feel free to DM me if you want to chat through this in more detail :)

text:
On another topic...

I'm working on deploying an ERC721 NFT set that is deployed as soul-bound to another NFT set's TBAs. I think I can do this without an initial mint, by for example having the derivative set's

function just always return the TBA for the parent NFT with the same ID. This is really exciting because we can just "declare into existence", say, a purse that every Milady just has by definition.

But one thing is stumping me, and there may not be a good solution: the ERC721 balanceOf() function. Given that a TBA is an EOA before being initialized, and also given the way that these are determined (hashes!), I can't think of a way to ask the question in Solidity I need to ask, which I think is: "is the address 0x123 a TBA of the NFT contract 0x345?" If I can ask that question, then it's trivial... But iiuc, there's no way to be able to look at any address and always know, yes or no, whether it's a TBA of a given NFT set.

text_entities.text:
On another topic...

I'm working on deploying an ERC721 NFT set that is deployed as soul-bound to another NFT set's TBAs. I think I can do this without an initial mint, by for example having the derivative set's
ownerOf(id)

function just always return the TBA for the parent NFT with the same ID. This is really exciting because we can just "declare into existence", say, a purse that every Milady just has by definition.

But one thing is stumping me, and there may not be a good solution: the ERC721 balanceOf() function. Given that a TBA is an EOA before being initialized, and also given the way that these are determined (hashes!), I can't think of a way to ask the question in Solidity I need to ask, which I think is: "is the address 0x123 a TBA of the NFT contract 0x345?" If I can ask that question, then it's trivial... But iiuc, there's no way to be able to look at any address and always know, yes or no, whether it's a TBA of a given NFT set.

text:
Quick reminder:

Thank you everyone for joining this working group! A few important rules:

1. Everyone here is a builder and actively providing opinions or contributing to the open source standard

2. We'll try to keep memes to a minimum and will enforce if it gets too out of hands. The purpose of this group is to build together and to share work or ask questions about ERC 6551

3. We have weekly dev/design calls on Thursdays

4. At any time, we encourage people to share their MVPs or projects using ERC 6551/TBAs. However no promotions for airdrops or projects that you are launching. We want to keep this group focused on building and on dev related questions.

5. We're here to rally the community towards making NFTs an awesome thing to own and collect. We mostly come from a development perspective rather than a shilling one, so please be mindful of that

6. The biggest contribuition you can make to this open standard is to share your feedback here:
7. If you have any issues with the SDK

or with anything feel free to share your questions in this group

8. Be nice. Be friendly. Be helpful to each other. No harrassment is tolerated and will be removed immediately. 

9. All constructive ideas are welcomed and we encourage healthy debates. We are aware that the NFT ecosystem is huge and there are so many projects that have different use cases. ERC 6551 is designed to be flexible, composable, and open so that anyone can customize it as they see fit.

10. When referencing ERC 6551 we usually call them Token Bound Accounts (TBAs). That is the most technically correct term.

text_entities.text:
Quick reminder:

Thank you everyone for joining this working group! A few important rules:

1. Everyone here is a builder and actively providing opinions or contributing to the open source standard

2. We'll try to keep memes to a minimum and will enforce if it gets too out of hands. The purpose of this group is to build together and to share work or ask questions about ERC 6551

3. We have weekly dev/design calls on Thursdays
https://calendar.google.com/calendar/u/1/r?cid=Y185OTNjZmNjOGRjNWE5MDdlM2Y1N2M4YWI0NTQwYzRiMTVhNTQ4ODc2YmQ0OWMyMWEwYmExY2RkMGU2MDE4ZjVhQGdyb3VwLmNhbGVuZGFyLmdvb2dsZS5jb20

4. At any time, we encourage people to share their MVPs or projects using ERC 6551/TBAs. However no promotions for airdrops or projects that you are launching. We want to keep this group focused on building and on dev related questions.

5. We're here to rally the community towards making NFTs an awesome thing to own and collect. We mostly come from a development perspective rather than a shilling one, so please be mindful of that

6. The biggest contribuition you can make to this open standard is to share your feedback here:
https://ethereum-magicians.org/t/erc-6551-non-fungible-token-bound-accounts/13030
7. If you have any issues with the SDK
https://docs.tokenbound.org/

or with anything feel free to share your questions in this group

8. Be nice. Be friendly. Be helpful to each other. No harrassment is tolerated and will be removed immediately. 

9. All constructive ideas are welcomed and we encourage healthy debates. We are aware that the NFT ecosystem is huge and there are so many projects that have different use cases. ERC 6551 is designed to be flexible, composable, and open so that anyone can customize it as they see fit.

10. When referencing ERC 6551 we usually call them Token Bound Accounts (TBAs). That is the most technically correct term.

Hello everyone,

I'm interested in hearing your thoughts on the concept of linking an SBT to a TBA. Given that the account is constantly transferable, it could be seen as a logical approach where the SBT serves as a means to track and advance achievements (if the TBA is used in a way for gaming)

are there any other ideas

text_entities.text:
Hello everyone,

I'm interested in hearing your thoughts on the concept of linking an SBT to a TBA. Given that the account is constantly transferable, it could be seen as a logical approach where the SBT serves as a means to track and advance achievements (if the TBA is used in a way for gaming)

are there any other ideas

messages.text: correct me if im wrong too 🙏

text_entities.text: correct me if im wrong too 🙏

messages.text:
It's only my opinion but I think the two main points of a TBA are actually:

-Great organizing, by creating a clear possession inheritance line if you follow some structure.

-The mean to "transfer" a big amount of different possessions in one transaction.
=> In theory you can transfer hundreds or thousands of Erc20 + ERC721 + ERC1155 (and more) by just sending the NFT owning the TBA.

Now if you actually link a TBA to a SBT, you forego the second of the two main strengths, and only keep the organizing advantage.
Which is still pretty solid in my opinion.

I'm actually building TBAs for SBTs.
To do what you just said :
" the SBT serves as a means to track and advance achievements".
It allows to store & organize very well and also potentially deleting/burning a huge chunk of info (or possession) in only 1 tx.

messages.text: Hi there! Was looking into the docs and was wondering if an NFT's private key can be used to sign something?

text_entities.text: Hi there! Was looking into the docs and was wondering if an NFT's private key can be used to sign something?

messages.text: Specifically, could you use the NFT’s private key to encrypt a string and only let the owner of the NFT decrypt it?

text_entities.text: Specifically, could you use the NFT’s private key to encrypt a string and only let the owner of the NFT decrypt it?

messages.text: There is no private key associated with the TBA itself as it is a smart contract wallet. You can sign messgaes by using the wallet that owns the NFT, but there are some challenges when it comes to encryption because the owner of the NFT can change at any time

messages.text: It should already be verified on mainnet (unless you're trying to deploy a custom implementation). You need to use the "is this a proxy" button on etherscan to link the account to the verified implementation address. It's not possible to verify the account bytecode directly since it is written in raw bytecode

text: Depending on what the subject is for the transfer, there are a couple different answers. If you mean transferring assets which are owned by an NFT’s account, you’ll want to take a look at the ‘executeCall’ function. You can call this directly via the account’s contract, or use the SDK

Otherwise, transferring the top-level token is just a matter of calling the usual method on the NFT contract like any standard NFT transfer.

Happy to go into more detail, let me know if I’m understanding your question correctly!

text_entities.text: Depending on what the subject is for the transfer, there are a couple different answers. If you mean transferring assets which are owned by an NFT’s account, you’ll want to take a look at the ‘executeCall’ function. You can call this directly via the account’s contract, or use the SDK
https://docs.tokenbound.org/sdk/methods

Otherwise, transferring the top-level token is just a matter of calling the usual method on the NFT contract like any standard NFT transfer.

Happy to go into more detail, let me know if I’m understanding your question correctly!

text:
Quick reminder:

Thank you everyone for joining this working group! A few important rules:

1. Everyone here is a builder and actively providing opinions or contributing to the open source standard

2. We'll try to keep memes to a minimum and will enforce if it gets too out of hands. The purpose of this group is to build together and to share work or ask questions about ERC 6551

3. We have weekly dev/design calls on Thursdays

4. At any time, we encourage people to share their MVPs or projects using ERC 6551/TBAs. However no promotions for airdrops or projects that you are launching. We want to keep this group focused on building and on dev related questions.

5. We're here to rally the community towards making NFTs an awesome thing to own and collect. We mostly come from a development perspective rather than a shilling one, so please be mindful of that

6. The biggest contribuition you can make to this open standard is to share your feedback here:
7. If you have any issues with the SDK

or with anything feel free to share your questions in this group

8. Be nice. Be friendly. Be helpful to each other. No harrassment is tolerated and will be removed immediately. 

9. All constructive ideas are welcomed and we encourage healthy debates. We are aware that the NFT ecosystem is huge and there are so many projects that have different use cases. ERC 6551 is designed to be flexible, composable, and open so that anyone can customize it as they see fit.

10. When referencing ERC 6551 we usually call them Token Bound Accounts (TBAs). That is the most technically correct term.

text_entities.text:
Quick reminder:

Thank you everyone for joining this working group! A few important rules:

1. Everyone here is a builder and actively providing opinions or contributing to the open source standard

2. We'll try to keep memes to a minimum and will enforce if it gets too out of hands. The purpose of this group is to build together and to share work or ask questions about ERC 6551

3. We have weekly dev/design calls on Thursdays
https://calendar.google.com/calendar/u/1/r?cid=Y185OTNjZmNjOGRjNWE5MDdlM2Y1N2M4YWI0NTQwYzRiMTVhNTQ4ODc2YmQ0OWMyMWEwYmExY2RkMGU2MDE4ZjVhQGdyb3VwLmNhbGVuZGFyLmdvb2dsZS5jb20

4. At any time, we encourage people to share their MVPs or projects using ERC 6551/TBAs. However no promotions for airdrops or projects that you are launching. We want to keep this group focused on building and on dev related questions.

5. We're here to rally the community towards making NFTs an awesome thing to own and collect. We mostly come from a development perspective rather than a shilling one, so please be mindful of that

6. The biggest contribuition you can make to this open standard is to share your feedback here:
https://ethereum-magicians.org/t/erc-6551-non-fungible-token-bound-accounts/13030
7. If you have any issues with the SDK
https://docs.tokenbound.org/

or with anything feel free to share your questions in this group

8. Be nice. Be friendly. Be helpful to each other. No harrassment is tolerated and will be removed immediately. 

9. All constructive ideas are welcomed and we encourage healthy debates. We are aware that the NFT ecosystem is huge and there are so many projects that have different use cases. ERC 6551 is designed to be flexible, composable, and open so that anyone can customize it as they see fit.

10. When referencing ERC 6551 we usually call them Token Bound Accounts (TBAs). That is the most technically correct term.

text: Here's an example using viem

text.text:
const { request } = await viemPublicClient({ chainId }).simulateContract({
                    address: tbAccountAddress as `0x${string}`,
                    abi: erc6551AccountAbi as Abi,
                    functionName: 'executeCall',
                    args: [recipient, weiValue, '0x'],
                    account: walletClient?.account,
                })

 await walletClient?.writeContract(request)

text: You can do the same with ethers, you'll need to simulate the contract, and then pass it through your EOA's wallet to sign the tx. For the wallet, you'll need to create an ethers wallet and pass through your private key of your EOA

text_entities.text: Here's an example using viem

const { request } = await viemPublicClient({ chainId }).simulateContract({
                    address: tbAccountAddress as `0x${string}`,
                    abi: erc6551AccountAbi as Abi,
                    functionName: 'executeCall',
                    args: [recipient, weiValue, '0x'],
                    account: walletClient?.account,
                })

 await walletClient?.writeContract(request)

You can do the same with ethers, you'll need to simulate the contract, and then pass it through your EOA's wallet to sign the tx. For the wallet, you'll need to create an ethers wallet and pass through your private key of your EOA

messages.text:
What’s the optimal flow for TBA NFTs minted to a Smart wallet?

Feels weird to have a smart wallet created for a user which mints an NFT which owns a smart wallet. Because that’s two wallets that the application has to manage

Examples or thoughts appreciated!

text_entities.text:
What’s the optimal flow for TBA NFTs minted to a Smart wallet?

Feels weird to have a smart wallet created for a user which mints an NFT which owns a smart wallet. Because that’s two wallets that the application has to manage

Examples or thoughts appreciated!

messages.text:
Can you explain a bit more on what do you mean when  you say “minted to a smart wallet”?
The TBA in itself is the wallet

text_entities.text:
Can you explain a bit more on what do you mean when  you say “minted to a smart wallet”?
The TBA in itself is the wallet

messages.text: Yes, so say my application is appealing to web 2 users so it assigns a smart wallet to them in order to be able to mint an NFT. And that NFT has a TBA. Now there are two managed wallets on behalf of the user

text_entities.text: Yes, so say my application is appealing to web 2 users so it assigns a smart wallet to them in order to be able to mint an NFT. And that NFT has a TBA. Now there are two managed wallets on behalf of the user

messages.text: So I guess my question is, should I be managing both, or is there a different suggested method?

text_entities.text: So I guess my question is, should I be managing both, or is there a different suggested method?

messages.text:
Oh i see what you mean. I’m not sure if there’s a suggested management method for it, but how about you create a smart contract wallet on the backend but the user only ever knows and interacts with the TBA via the NFT that is owned in the smart contract wallet. 
So the user never knows there’s a smart contract wallet at all, they only care and interact with the NFT. If and when they want to exit, the app allows them to transfer the NFT to whatever address they want to

messages.text: the executeCall returned from tokenbound sdk has the value param set to the value that you passed. So what ends up happening is that the TBA owner sends the ETH along with the tx. You can prevent it by updating the executeCall before sending the tx like this^

text: SDK 0.3.6 is up!

- Fixes an issue with executeCall when using walletClient
- Introduces revised testing rubric (spin up local Anvil node via viem/anvil)
- Explicit executeCall send in example Apps
- Explicit export of TBAccountParams
- Adds optional publicClient param to TokenboundClient (used for anvil testing)
- Remove act() from E2E tests (already enforced inside wagmi renderer)
- Extensive cleanup

messages.text: Hello there, been looking into trying TBAs for a side project… just wondering if I’m grasping the 4337 related concepts properly.  It is not necessary to deploy my own EntryPoint contract at all, and if i want to override the validation behavior, I just need to override the _validateSignature implementation in my own custom Account implementation? In the future if a new version of the EntryPoint is released, I would just need to create a new Account implementation for the new EntryPoint, then upgrade the TBAs via proxy or beacon?
